title: Floyd v. Morgan
description: We reverse the decision of the Court of Appeals in Floyd v. Morgan, 375 S.C. 246, 652 S.E.2d 83 (Ct. App. 2007), which affirmed the family court's order reducing Respondent's child support obligation and denying Petitioner's request for attorney's fees.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Sherrie Jean
      Floyd, Respondent,
				v.
				Richard Morgan,
      Jr., Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Lexington County
RollyÂ  W.Â  Jacobs, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 26681
Heard May 13, 2009 - Filed July 6, 2009Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				J. Mark
  Taylor, of Moore Taylor & Thomas, of W. Columbia, and Katherine C. Goode,
  of Winnsboro, for Petitioner.
				Richard G.
  Whiting and Spencer A. Syrett, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  In this domestic relations case, Sherrie Jean Floyd
  (Mother) moved to reduce the amount of her child support payment to Richard
  Morgan, Jr. (Father).Â  After the family court granted this reduction and denied
  each partyâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees, Father appealed the order to the
  Court of Appeals.Â  In a divided decision, the Court of Appeals affirmed the
  family courtâ€™s order.Â  Floyd v. Morgan, 375 S.C. 246, 652 S.E.2d 83 (Ct.
  App. 2007).Â  This Court granted Fatherâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari.Â  We
  reverse the decision of the Court of Appeals and remand this case to family
  court.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
By
  order dated August 30, 2000, the family court granted Father a divorce from
  Mother on the ground of adultery.Â  Prior to the issuance of this order, the
  parties entered into a custody, support, and property settlement agreement.Â  Pursuant
  to this agreement, the court granted Father custody of the partiesâ€™ two minor
  children, ages six and eight, and granted Mother visitation in excess of 109
  overnights per year.[1] Â 
Because
  Motherâ€™s visitation exceeded 109 overnights per year, it satisfied the
  threshold amount to constitute a shared custody arrangement.[2]Â 
  The parties, however, agreed to calculate Motherâ€™s child support obligation
  pursuant to a sole custody arrangement which resulted in an amount of support
  greater than under a shared custody calculation.Â  Specifically, this agreement
  provided:Â  â€œMother shall directly pay Father the amount of $920.00 per month in
  child support based upon figures set forth in the attached Child Support
  Obligation Worksheet A.â€ Â The family court approved the agreement and
  incorporated it into the divorce decree.Â  
In May 2004, Mother
  sought sole custody of the children or, in the alternative, a shared or joint
  custody arrangement.Â  Additionally, Mother requested modification of her child
  support obligation.Â  
In June 2005, due
  to an increase in Fatherâ€™s income and a decrease in Motherâ€™s income, the
  parties agreed they would temporarily reduce Motherâ€™s child support payment
  from $920 to $808 per month while the action was pending.Â  By consent order, the
  court approved the partiesâ€™ agreement. 
In January 2006,
  Mother and Father agreed to modify their original agreement regarding the
  timing of Motherâ€™s visitation.Â  They did not, however, modify the number of
  Motherâ€™s overnight visits with the children.Â  The family court approved this
  modification.
Despite these
  modifications, the parties failed to reach an agreement concerning the
  following two issues:Â  (1) Motherâ€™s request to permanently reduce her child
  support obligation, and (2) both Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s requests for attorneyâ€™s
  fees and costs.Â  In terms of the child support reduction, the parties disputed
  whether child support should be calculated in accordance with Worksheet A (for
  sole custody) of the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines (the Guidelines),
  as referenced in the partiesâ€™ agreement, or Worksheet C (for shared custody) of
  the Guidelines.Â  
After a hearing,
  the family court[3] granted Motherâ€™s request to modify the provisions of the original divorce
  decree regarding child support.Â  In so ruling, the court found the 43% increase
  in Fatherâ€™s income and the elimination of child care expenses in the amount of
  $544.00 per month constituted a substantial change of circumstances. 
The
  family court calculated Motherâ€™s new child support obligation pursuant to
  Worksheet C (shared custody) of the Guidelines and reduced Motherâ€™s support
  payment to $152 per month.Â  Although the court recognized the partiesâ€™
  agreement specified that child support calculations would be made using
  Worksheet A (sole custody), the court believed it could exercise its discretion
  to choose between the two methods of calculation.Â  
In
  explaining this ultimate calculation, the court considered the fact that
  Motherâ€™s current visitation was 147 days and that she had spent approximately
  $3,000 in expenses above her child support obligation.Â  
Additionally,
  the court found each party should be responsible for his or her own attorneyâ€™s
  fees and costs.
Father appealed the
  family courtâ€™s order to the Court of Appeals.Â  In a divided opinion, the Court
  of Appeals affirmed the family courtâ€™s reduction of Motherâ€™s child support
  obligation and denied Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s requests for attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs.Â  Floyd v. Morgan, 375 S.C. 246, 652 S.E.2d 83 (Ct. App. 2007).
Relying
  solely on this Courtâ€™s decision in Rogers v. Rogers, 343 S.C. 329, 540
  S.E.2d 840 (2001),[4] the Court of Appeals found the increase in Fatherâ€™s income as compared to
  Motherâ€™s, the elimination of child care expenses, and the consistent amount of
  medical expenses since the divorce constituted a substantial change of
  circumstances which warranted a modification of Motherâ€™s child support
  obligation.Â  Id. at 251, 652 S.E.2d at 86.Â  
In
  reaching this conclusion, the Court of Appeals pointed out that at the time of
  the divorce in 2000, Father earned $4,000 per month whereas Mother earned
  $4,067.Â  By the time of the initial hearing in 2004, Fatherâ€™s monthly income
  increased 29% to $5,150, while Motherâ€™s income only increased 18% to $4,800.Â  In
  2005, Fatherâ€™s income increased to $5,421, while Motherâ€™s income decreased to
  $4,785.Â  At the time of the final hearing in 2006, Fatherâ€™s income increased to
  $5,700, whereas Motherâ€™s income returned to $4,800.Â  According to the family
  court and the Court of Appeals, these income fluctuations represented a 43%
  increase to Fatherâ€™s income since 2000 compared to only an 18% increase to
  Motherâ€™s income.Â  Id. at 251, 652 S.E.2d at 86.
Referencing
  several provisions of section 20-7-852[5] of the South Carolina Code and the accompanying Regulations 114-4720 and
  114-4730,[6] the Court of Appeals held the trial court had discretion to apply Worksheet C, the
  shared custody guidelines, upon Motherâ€™s showing of a substantial change of
  circumstances.Â  Id. at 254, 652 S.E.2d at 88.Â Â  
Because
  Motherâ€™s visitations were approximately 147 overnights per year, which clearly
  exceeded the 109 overnight visits required to put into effect the shared
  parenting provisions of the Guidelines, the Court of Appeals found Worksheet C
  was the appropriate method of calculating a reduction in Motherâ€™s child support
  obligation.Â  Id. at 253, 652 S.E.2d at 87.
Although
  the Court of Appeals acknowledged the terms of the partiesâ€™ 2000 agreement and
  the family courtâ€™s incorporation of this agreement into the divorce decree, the
  Court of Appeals dismissed it as inconsequential on the grounds the 2000
  divorce decree:Â  1) did not explain why there was a deviation from the amount
  that should have presumably been awarded by application of the Guidelines, and
  2) did not bind the parties to use Worksheet A in future child support
  calculations based on a change of circumstances.Â  Id. Â Citing this
  Courtâ€™s decision in Moseley v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 306 S.E.2d 624
  (1983), the Court of Appeals explained that â€œa merged child support agreement
  loses its contractual character after it is judicially decreed.â€Â  Id. at 253, 652 S.E.2d at 87.
Having
  found the family court did not err in reducing Motherâ€™s child support
  obligation and the parties had settled the custody aspect of the case, the Court
  of Appeals affirmed the denial of Fatherâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs.Â  Id. at 255, 652 S.E.2d at 88.
This
  Court granted Fatherâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the decision
  of the Court of Appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find
  facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Strickland
    v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76, 82, 650 S.E.2d 465, 468 (2007).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require the reviewing
  court to disregard the findings of the family court. Â Id.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.
Father
  contends the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the family courtâ€™s reduction
  of child support to the amount established by an application of Worksheet C of
  the Guidelines.Â  If a modification of Motherâ€™s child support obligation was
  warranted, Father claims any calculation should have been made pursuant to
  Worksheet A in accordance with the partiesâ€™ agreement.Â  
A child support award rests in the discretion of the trial judge,
  and will not be altered on appeal absent abuse of discretion. Â Hallums v.
    Hallums, 296 S.C. 195, 197, 371 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1988). 
â€œThe family court may always modify child support upon a proper
  showing of a change in either the
  childâ€™s needs or the supporting parentâ€™s financial ability.â€ Â Upchurch v.
    Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 26, 624 S.E.2d 643, 647-48 (2006); Calvert v.
      Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 336 S.E.2d 884 (Ct App. 1985) (recognizing that a
  substantial or material change of circumstances must occur to warrant a
  modification of child support).Â  â€œThe party seeking the modification has the
  burden to show changed circumstances.â€ Â Upchurch, 367 S.C. at 26, 624
  S.E.2d at 648.Â  Â â€œThis burden is increased where the child support award is
  based on a settlement agreement.â€Â  Id. Â â€œHowever, changes within the
  contemplation of the parties at the time of the initial decree are not
  sufficient bases for the modification of a child support award.â€Â  Id.Â Â  Moreover, â€œa reduction in child support cannot be based on a decrease
  in the noncustodial parentâ€™s income absent a strong showing by the latter that he
  or she can no longer make the support payments required by the earlier order.â€Â  Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73-74, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119-20 (Ct. App. 2003).
As evidenced by the above-cited case law, an analysis
  of Motherâ€™s request for modification of a child support obligation involves two
  questions:Â  (1) did Mother prove that a substantial or material change of
  circumstances occurred to justify a reduction; and (2) if a reduction was
  warranted, what method of calculation was appropriate?
We
  agree with the Court of Appeals that upon a finding of a substantial change in
  circumstances the family court judge has discretion to utilize any Worksheet he
  or she finds appropriate under the facts of the case.Â  However, in the case sub
    judice, we disagree that a substantial change in circumstances warranting a
  change in support has occurred.Â  We conclude that Mother failed to meet the
  heightened burden necessary to warrant a downward modification of her child support
  obligation.[7]Â  
Initially,
  we find the Court of Appealsâ€™ reliance on Rogers was erroneous.Â  In Rogers, Mother petitioned the family court for an increase in Fatherâ€™s child
  support obligation based on Fatherâ€™s increase in income.Â  In contrast, Mother,
  in the instant case, petitioned the family court for a decrease in her child
  support obligation based on Fatherâ€™s increase in income.Â  Because the Court of
  Appeals relied exclusively on Rogers, we believe the evident factual
  dissimilarities of this case undermine the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision to find a
  substantial change of circumstances.
Although
  the increase in Fatherâ€™s income is of some import, this factor alone did not
  warrant a downward modification of Motherâ€™s obligation absent a strong showing
  that she was incapable of meeting the initial agreed-upon amount of child
  support.Â  See Miller v. Miller, 299 S.C. 307, 384 S.E.2d 715
  (1989) (finding Father failed to establish substantial or material change of
  circumstances warranting modification of his child support obligation where
  Fatherâ€™s financial declaration did not show that he was incapable of paying the
  previously-ordered support even though his income had decreased, Motherâ€™s
  income had increased, and her expenses had decreased); see also Penny
    v. Green, 357 S.C. 583, 594 S.E.2d 171 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding decrease in
  Fatherâ€™s income from $140,000 to $120,000 was not sufficient to constitute a
  substantial change in circumstances to warrant a reduction of his child support
  obligation); Â Kielar v. Kielar, 311 S.C. 466, 429 S.E.2d 851 (Ct. App.
  1993) (concluding Fatherâ€™s involuntary resignation resulting in a salary
  decrease from $300,000 to $180,000 per year did not constitute a substantial
  change in circumstances given it did not impact on Fatherâ€™s standard of living
  or his ability to pay his support obligations); Calvert, 287 S.C. at
  138, 336 S.E.2d at 888 (finding no substantial or material change of
  circumstances despite reduction in Fatherâ€™s income and stating â€œ[t]he mere fact
  that a supporting spouseâ€™s salary or income has been reduced does not of itself
  require a reduction of either alimony or child supportâ€).
Based
  on the foregoing, Mother had to prove more than an increase in Fatherâ€™s income
  to warrant a downward modification of her child support obligation.Â  Mother
  failed to do so given her income actually increased 18% since the 2000 order
  and, thus, she could not establish that she was incapable of meeting the
  initially agreed-upon child support obligation of $920 per month. 
Furthermore,
  we find the other factors relied upon by the family court and the Courts of
  Appeals were within the contemplation of the parties at the time of the initial
  decree.Â  
First,
  given the childrenâ€™s young ages at the time of the initial decree, we believe
  the parties would have foreseen the eventual elimination of the $544 child care
  expense used to calculate Motherâ€™s initial child support obligation.Â  Moreover,
  Regulation 114-4720 points out that support payments are based on data
  reflecting the average cost of rearing a child to its age of majority.Â  This
  Regulation also recognizes that this cost increases as the childâ€™s age
  increases.Â  27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720 (Supp. 2006).Â  Therefore, the
  reduction in child care cost is offset over time by the increase in cost
  associated with the needs of an aging or maturing child.Â  Thus, it would appear
  that a reduction in child care cost is expected and considered in the child
  support guidelines formulation.
Secondly,
  the overnight liberal visitation schedule did not change. Â Clearly, the parties
  could have conceived that additional expenses would arise during the childrenâ€™s
  extensive visits with Mother.Â  See Upchurch, 367 S.C. at 26, 624
  S.E.2d at 648 (stating â€œchanges within the contemplation of the parties at the
  time of the initial decree are not sufficient bases for the modification of a
  child support awardâ€).
Accordingly,
  we hold Mother failed to meet her burden of proving a substantial or material
  change of circumstances justifying a modification of her agreed-upon child
  support obligation.Â  Because a modification was not warranted, we need not
  address Fatherâ€™s issue regarding the recalculation of Motherâ€™s child support
  obligation.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of
    Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (recognizing an appellate court need not
  address additional issues if the resolution of another issue is dispositive).
II.
Finally,
  Father asserts this Court should reverse the decision of the Court of Appeals
  to affirm the family courtâ€™s denial of Fatherâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees and
  costs.Â  Â Â 
Because
  we reverse the Court of Appeals on the child support issue, we also reverse and
  remand to the family court the issue regarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  See Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 503, 427 S.E.2d 665, 666
  (1993) (reversing and remanding issue of attorneyâ€™s fees for reconsideration
  when the substantive results achieved by trial counsel were reversed on
  appeal). 
CONCLUSION
We
  find Mother failed to satisfy her heightened burden of proving that a
  substantial or material change of circumstances existed to justify a
  modification of her agreed-upon child support obligation.Â  Therefore, we
  reverse the decision of the Court of Appeals and remand this case to the family
  court for a reconsideration of the issue concerning an award of attorneyâ€™s fees
  and costs.
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1]  Although the agreement did not specifically identify
  the number of overnight visits allotted to Mother, it set forth a weekly,
  monthly, and holiday time schedule.Â  Based on this schedule, Mother was granted
  147 overnight visits per year. 
[2]  See 27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4730(A) (Supp. 2007) (â€œ[S]hared physical custody
  means that each parent has court-ordered visitation with the children overnight
  for more than 109 overnights each year (30%) and that both parents contribute
  to the expenses of the child(ren) in addition to the payment of child
  support.â€).Â  
[3]Â  We note the family court judge who heard the 2006
  action for modification of child support was not the same judge who issued the
  2000 decree of divorce. 
[4]Â  In Rogers, this Court found Mother was
  entitled to an increase in child support based on a 21% increase in Fatherâ€™s
  income and an increase in child care expenses.Â  Rogers, 343 S.C. at 333,
  540 S.E.2d at 842.
[5]  The Court of Appeals referenced several subsections
  of section 20-7-852 which governs the award and modification of child support.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-852(A)-(C) (Supp. 2006).Â  We note this code section is
  now designated as section 63-17-470 pursuant to the General Assemblyâ€™s
  restructuring of the Childrenâ€™s Code.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-17-470 (2009); S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-852 (Supp. 2008).Â  Because this case arose prior to the
  re-codification, we use the former statutory citations.
[6]Â  These Guidelines govern child support awards as
  provided in section 20-7-852 of the South Carolina Code.Â  27 S.C. Code Ann.
  Regs. 114-4720, 114-4730 (Supp. 2006). 
[7]Â  While we recognize the parties agreed to reduce
  Motherâ€™s child support obligation from $920 to $808 per month while the action
  was pending, we do not construe this voluntary modification as an explicit
  concession on the part of Father that a change of circumstances existed to
  warrant a permanent reduction.

title: Berkeley County School District v. SCDOR
description: In this original jurisdiction case, the Court reviews the South Carolina Department of Revenue's decision denying Plaintiffs reimbursement from the Homestead Exemption Fund for expenses incurred under lease purchase and installment-purchase agreement obligations for capital improvement projects.  We grant judgment for the Plaintiffs.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Berkeley County
      School District, Lexington County School District No. 1, Lexington County
      School District No. 4, Orangeburg County Consolidated School District Five,
      School District No. 1 of Spartanburg County, and School District No. 5 of
      Spartanburg County, Plaintiffs,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Revenue, Defendant.
			
		
	


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No.Â  26682
Heard January 8, 2009 - Filed July 6, 2009Â  
JUDGMENT FOR PLAINTIFFS


	
		
			
				Steve A.
  Matthews, Theodore B. DuBose and R. David Proffitt, all of Columbia, for Plaintiffs Berkeley County School District, Lexington County School District No.
  1, and Lexington County School District No. 4.
				Daniel
  R. McLeod, Jr., Francenia B. Heizer and Eve Ross, all of Columbia, for Plaintiffs Orangeburg County
  Consolidated School District Five, School District No. 1 of Spartanburg County,
  and School District No. 5 of Spartanburg County.
				William
  F. Halligan and Keith R. Powell, of Columbia, for Plaintiffs Berkeley County School District, Lexington
  County School District No. 1, Lexington County School District No. 4,
  Orangeburg County Consolidated School District Five, School District No. 1 of
  Spartanburg County, and School District No. 5 of Spartanburg County.
				Milton
  G. Kimpson, Ronald W. Urban, Ray N. Stevens, Harry T. Cooper, Jr. and Nicholas
  P. Sipe, all of Columbia, for Defendant.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  The Plaintiffs, the above-listed school districts, filed this action
  for a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief in this Courtâ€™s original
  jurisdiction pursuant to S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 5, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-310
  (1976), and Rule 245 (formerly Rule 229), SCACR.Â  The Court granted the
  Plaintiffsâ€™ petition and now reviews the South Carolina Department of Revenueâ€™s
  (the Departmentâ€™s) decision denying the Plaintiffs reimbursement from the
  Homestead Exemption Fund[1] for expenses incurred under lease-purchase and installment-purchase agreement
  obligations for capital improvement projects.Â  Because these expenses are used
  for â€œschool operating purposes,â€ for which owner-occupied residential property
  is tax exempt, we find the Plaintiffs are entitled to reimbursement for the
  taxes lost as a result of this exemption.Â  Accordingly, we grant the
  Plaintiffsâ€™ request for a declaratory judgment.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In
  past years, the Plaintiffs have entered into lease-purchase agreements and
  installment-purchase agreements to obtain the current use of, and as a method
  of financing, new and renovated school buildings and other school-related facilities.Â 
  The school districts have utilized these types of agreements as alternative
  financing mechanisms that do not constitute â€œgeneral obligation debt.â€[2]
Under
  the lease-purchase agreements, a school district would typically lease its land
  and buildings to a non-profit corporation for a long period of time.Â  After
  execution of the year-to-year lease, the corporation would privately raise
  funds to finance the school renovation and construction by selling certificates
  of participation to investors.Â  The school districtsâ€™ payments are set at an
  amount sufficient to pay the principal and interest due under the certificates
  of participation and are made from the proceeds of school district taxes levied
  for general fund purposes.Â  In a lease-purchase transaction, ownership of the
  facilities transfers at the end of the lease term.Â  The agreements include a
  non-appropriation clause that permits the school districts to decline, without
  penalty, to renew the annual lease by failing or refusing to appropriate
  necessary funds for payments.Â  
In
  terms of the installment-purchase agreements, the school districts convey the
  existing school facilities to the non-profit corporation and lease the land on
  which these facilities sit to the corporation.Â  In turn, the corporation will
  then issue corporate revenue bonds to fund the renovation of the existing
  facilities and the construction of new facilities.Â  The school districts,
  instead of annual payments, make yearly purchases of an undivided partial
  ownership interest in certain facilities at a sale price set at an amount
  sufficient to pay the principal and interest due under the financial
  obligations issued by the corporation.Â  Pursuant to this type of agreement,
  undivided partial ownership of the facilities transfers with each installment
  payment.Â  The school districts use taxes levied for general fund purposes to
  make the annual installment purchases.Â  These agreements include a
  non-appropriation clause.
In
  1988 and 1994, this Court issued decisions holding that lease-purchase
  agreements and installment-purchase agreements do not constitute general
  obligation debt.Â  Redmond v. Lexington County Sch. Dist. No. Four,
  314 S.C. 431, 445 S.E.2d 441 (1994) (discussing Caddell and finding
  school board had authority to enter into lease-purchase agreements to build a
  new school without submitting the matter to voters); Caddell v. Lexington
    County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 296 S.C. 397, 373 S.E.2d 598 (1988) (holding that
  lease-purchase agreements do not constitute general obligation debt under
  Article X, Â§ 15 of the South Carolina Constitution).
In
  1995, the General Assembly enacted, and in 2006 amended, section 11-27-110[3] to limit lease-purchase agreements and installment-purchase agreements.Â  As a
  result of the 2006 amendment, the General Assembly specifically prohibited
  school districts from entering into such agreements without voter approval if counting
  the proposed transaction would cause the school district to exceed its
  constitutional debt limit.
In
  response to the General Assemblyâ€™s pronouncement, the school districts
  continued to utilize different variations of these types of agreements as
  financing mechanisms that did not constitute, for constitutional purposes,
  general obligation debt and that did not meet the statutorily-defined criteria
  that the General Assembly pronounced to limit lease-purchase transactions.Â  After
  an installment-purchase agreement was specifically challenged as to its
  constitutionality, this Court refined its analysis holding that such an
  agreement did not constitute a â€œfinancing agreementâ€ as defined in section
  11-27-110(A)(6) at the time the agreement was entered into.Â  Colleton County Taxpayers Assâ€™n v. Sch. Dist. of Colleton County, 371 S.C. 224,
  638 S.E.2d 685 (2006).Â  
In
  so holding, the Court noted that section 11-27-110(A)(6) dealing with lease-purchase
  agreements had been substantially revised in 2006 to include and specifically
  define and explain lease-purchase and installment-purchase agreements entered
  into by school districts.Â  Id. at 232, 638 S.E.2d at 689.Â  Based on this
  amendment, the Court concluded that â€œ[t]he portion of Â§ 11-27-110(A)(6)
  currently in effect requires only that the school district use funds derived
  from the issuance of general obligation debt to make payments under an installment-purchase
  agreement.Â  So long as the School District abides by this requirement, they
  have not violated the statuteâ€™s requirements.â€Â  Id. at 236, 638 S.E.2d
  at 691.
In
  order to make payments on lease-purchase agreements, the school districts have
  used taxes levied on owner-occupied residential real property.Â  Between 1995
  and 2006, these properties received a property tax exemption on the first
  $100,000 of the propertyâ€™s fair market value for taxes â€œcalculated on the
  school operating millage imposed for tax year 1995 or the current school
  operating millage, whichever is lower, excluding taxes levied for bonded
  indebtedness and payments pursuant to lease purchase agreements for capital
    construction.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-37-251(A)(1) (2000) (emphasis
  added).Â  
In
  2006, the General Assembly increased the amount of the tax exemption for
  owner-occupied residential property to â€œone hundred percent of the fair market
  valueâ€ of the property and provided the property was â€œexempt from all property
  taxes imposed for school operating purposes but not including
  millage imposed for the repayment of general obligation debt.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  12-37-220(B)(47)(a) (Supp. 2007) (emphasis added).Â  In order to reimburse
  school districts for the revenue lost as a result of the exemption, the General
  Assembly imposed an additional one percent sales tax.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  12-36-1110 to -1130 (Supp. 2007) (outlining provisions for additional sales, use,
  and causal excise tax and directing taxes imposed under these sections to be
  credited to the Homestead Exemption Fund as established pursuant to section
  11-11-155).Â  In conjunction, the General Assembly established the â€œHomestead
  Exemption Fund,â€ in which the collected funds are deposited.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  11-11-155, 12-36-1120 (Supp. 2007).Â  Section 11-11-156 sets forth a three-tier

  operating millage portion of the reimbursement for the homestead exemption
  allowed pursuant to Section 12-37-250 ($50,000 homestead exemption for
  residents 65 or older and individuals who are permanently disabled or legally
  blind).Â  The tier two reimbursement is fixed at this fiscal year 2006-2007
  amount and continues into succeeding fiscal years at this fixed amount.
		(3) The
  tier three reimbursement consists of â€œan amount equal dollar for dollar to the
  revenue that would be collected by the district from property tax for school
  operating expenses imposed by the district on owner-occupied residential
  property for that fiscal year as if no reimbursed exemptions applied, plus an
  amount that a district may have received in its fiscal year 2006-2007 reimbursements
  pursuant to Section 12-37-251 in excess of the computed amount of that
  exemption from school operating millage for that year, reduced by the total of
  the districtâ€™s tier one and tier two reimbursements.â€
	
	The
  question before the Department is whether â€œproperty tax for school operating
  purposesâ€ includes the millage associated with financing agreements, such as
  lease purchase agreements for capital improvements.
	The term
  â€œproperty tax for school operating purposesâ€ is not defined in Section 11-11-156
  nor is it defined in the rest of the South Carolina Code of Laws.Â  This term,
  however, does have a generally accepted meaning within the local government and
  legislative community.Â  The term refers to amounts required for the general
  day-to-day operations of the school.Â  It does not include amounts for capital
  improvements financed either through debt obligations such as bonds or through
  other financing mechanisms such as lease purchase agreements.Â  The Legislature
  did not intend the term â€œoperatingâ€ to be ignored.Â  If the Legislature were
  referring to all property taxes used to finance schools, they would have used
  the terms â€œschool purposesâ€ or â€œall school purposes.â€
	Prior to
  the enactment of the Property Tax Reform Act, S.C. Code Ann. Section 12-37-251(A)
  (2000), provided the property tax exemption and State reimbursement for
  $100,000 of the fair market value of legal residences.Â  That exemption and
  reimbursement did not include bonded indebtedness or lease purchase agreements
  for capital construction.Â  There is no reason to believe that the Legislature
  intended to expand the exemption and State reimbursement in Section 11-11-156
  to include these items.
	This
  interpretation is supported by S.C. Code Ann. Section 6-1-320 (Supp. 2007).Â 
  Section 6-1-320 provides limitations on operating millage increases.Â  Section
  6-1-320(D) provides that the restrictions on operating millage increases do not
  â€œaffect millage that is levied to pay bonded indebtedness or payments for real
  property purchased using a lease-purchase agreement or used to maintain a
  reserve account.â€Â  In other words, millage for these items are not considered
  for â€œoperating purposesâ€ and school districts are still able to raise the
  millage to pay bonded indebtedness and lease purchase agreements for real
  property.Â  As a result, reimbursement by the State is not necessary.Â  Property
  taxes from all taxpayers, including property taxes for legal residences,
  continue to pay for capital improvements.
	Finally,
  in S.C. Code Ann. Section 11-27-110 (Supp. 2007) the Legislature expressed its
  interest in treating financing agreements, including lease purchase agreements,
  in the same manner as debt from bonds.Â  Both bonds and lease purchase
  agreements are methods of financing capital improvements.Â  Reimbursing
  districts that used lease purchase agreements to finance capital improvements
  and not reimbursing districts that used bonds to finance capital improvements
  is contrary to the legislative decision to treat these methods of financing in
  the same manner.
	Based on
  the foregoing, the reimbursements provided in Section 11-11-156 do not include
  (1) the millage imposed for general obligation debt; (2) millage imposed for
  financing agreements as defined in Section 11-27-110(A)(6) regardless of the
  date the contract for the financing agreement was entered into; or (3) any
  other agreement which is in substance a financing agreement for capital
  improvements.

II.
Plaintiffs
  challenge the Department of Revenueâ€™s statutory construction in this action.Â 
  If payments pursuant to the lease/installment-purchase agreements are
  considered school operating expenses, Plaintiffs are entitled to tier three
  reimbursements.Â  Conversely, if payments pursuant to the lease/installment-purchase
  agreements are not considered school operating expenses, owner-occupied
  residential property may be taxed for such purpose, and the school districts
  are not entitled to tier three reimbursements.Â  A majority of the Court agrees
  with Plaintiffs.Â  I do not.Â  I believe the phrase â€œschool operating purposesâ€
  creates no genuine ambiguity and means what it saysâ€”operational expenses, not
  capital improvements.
Plaintiffs,
  in their brief, assert section 12-37-220(B)(47) creates an exemption for owner-occupied
  homeowners for â€œall school property taxes.â€Â  Plaintiffsâ€™ brief is misleading,
  for the statute says no such thing.Â  The section 12-37-220(B)(47)(a) statutory
  exemption is limited to property taxes for â€œschool operating purposes,â€ an
  unambiguous term excluding capital construction projects.[15]
The
  Court today accepts Plaintiffsâ€™ premise of an ambiguity, and construes the â€œschool
  operating purposesâ€ exemption so broadly that we must conclude the Legislature
  intended no bounds.Â  The settled principle that a tax exemption must be
  strictly construed against the claimed exemption is ignored today.Â  TNS
    Mills, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 620, 503 S.E.2d 471,
  476 (1998) (â€œThe language of a tax exemption statute must be given its plain,
  ordinary meaning and must be strictly construed against the claimed
  exemption.â€).Â Â Â  
The
  Court takes the statutory term and exemption for â€œoperating purposesâ€ and
  instructs that â€œa school would not be operational without an infrastructure
  which necessarily includes school buildings.â€Â  We learn, therefore, that the
  Legislature intended the acquisition of property through capital improvements
  (clothed as lease/installment-purchase agreements) to be included as operating
  expenses, and thus subject to tier three reimbursements.Â  
I
  see no reason to depart from the common understanding of â€œoperating purposes.â€Â 
  Moreover, I see no reason to reject the statutory construction of the
  Department of Revenue.Â  See Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
    Control, 348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002) (â€œThe construction
  of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be accorded the
  most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling
  reasons.â€) (citation omitted).Â Â  
In
  my judgment, the Legislature has given no indication of an intent to broaden â€œschool
  operating purposesâ€ to include expenditures for capital construction under
  lease/installment-purchase agreements.Â  I believe the Legislature intends the
  very opposite.Â  For example, section 6-1-320 imposes limitations on a local governing
  bodyâ€™s authority to raise property tax millage rates for â€œgeneral operating
  purposes,â€ but the statute expressly relieves the local government from such
  restrictions for tax millage for lease/installment-purchase agreements: â€œThe
  restriction contained in this section does not affect millage that is levied to
  pay bonded indebtedness or payments for real property purchased using a
  lease-purchase agreement . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-1-320(D) (Supp. 2008).Â  I
  find it incongruous to suggest that the Legislature expressly lifted
  restrictions on increasing tax millage for payments on lease-purchase agreements
  if real property is not taxable for this purpose at all.
It
  is manifest in my judgment that the Legislature has authorized local governing
  bodies to levy taxes on real property for the payment of capital construction
  under lease/installment-purchase agreements.Â  I thus believe the Department of
  Revenueâ€™s statutory construction is buttressed by a review of the taxing
  statutory scheme as a whole.Â  In any event, were I to accept the premise of
  ambiguity in the phrase â€œschool operating purposes,â€ I see no compelling reason
  to depart from the construction assigned by the Department of Revenue. Brown,
  348 S.C. at 515, 560 S.E.2d at 414.
And
  finally, I observe that two of the school district plaintiffs also agree with
  the Department of Revenue and believe that lease-purchase agreements are not school
  operating expenses, and consequently are not included in the exemption.Â 
  Plaintiffs Lexington County School Districts No. 1 and No. 4 levied taxes on
  owner-occupied residential property to make payments on lease-purchase agreements
  for capital construction.[16]Â 
  I believe Lexington County School Districts No. 1 and No. 4 acted lawfully in
  taxing owner-occupied residential property to make payments on their respective
  lease-purchase agreements.Â  The conduct of these school districts juxtaposed to
  their position in this lawsuit is troubling, at least to me.Â  
TOAL,
  C.J., concurs.


[1]Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 11-11-155(A) (Supp. 2007) (â€œThe
  revenue from the tax imposed pursuant to Article 11, Chapter 36 of Title 12 is
  automatically credited to a fund separate and distinct from the state general
  fund known as the â€œHomestead Exemption Fund.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  11-11-156(A)(1) (Supp. 2007) (outlining three-tier reimbursement mechanism to
  reimburse school districts out of the Homestead Exemption Fund for taxes lost
  as a result of various property tax exemptions).
[2]Â General obligation debt has been defined by this
  Court as â€œonly debt that is â€˜secured . . . by a pledge of the [school
  districtâ€™s] full faith, credit and taxing power.â€™â€ Colleton County Taxpayers
    Assâ€™n v. Sch. Dist. of Colleton County, 371 S.C. 224, 234, 638 S.E.2d 685,
  690 (2006) (quoting Cadell v. Lexington County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 296
  S.C. 397, 400, 373 S.E.2d 598, 599 (1988)).Â  The amount of general obligation
  debt that a school district may incur is constitutionally limited by Article X,
  section 15 of the South Carolina Constitution, which provides in pertinent part,
  â€œthe governing body of any school
  district may incur general obligation debt in an amount not exceeding eight
  percent of the assessed value of all taxable property of such school district
  subject to the provisions of subsection (3) of this section and upon such terms
  and conditions as the General Assembly may prescribe.â€Â  S.C. Const. art. X, Â§
  15(6).Â  If the school district intends to exceed this constitutionally-limited
  amount, a majority of the voters in the school district must provide otherwise
  by referendum.Â  S.C. Const. art. X, Â§ 15(5).
[3]Â Act No. 55, 1995 S.C. Acts 348; Act No. 388, 2006
  S.C. Acts 3166.Â  Section 11-27-110(C) provides:

	(C) If
  a governmental entity described in subsection (A) (8)(b) of this section has
  outstanding any financing agreement, other than an enterprise financing
  agreement, a loan agreement for energy conservation measures as provided for in
  Section 48-52-650, or a lease purchase agreement for energy efficiency products
  as provided in Section 48-52-660, or a guaranteed energy savings contract as
  provided in Section 48-52-670, where no such lease agreement or contract shall
  constitute in any manner an agreement, consent, authority, or otherwise, to
  provide retail sales of energy by an energy or power provider or creates the
  authority to sell or provide retail energy or power, on the date of issuance of
  any limited bonded indebtedness pursuant to any bond act, the amount of this
    limited bonded indebtedness plus the amount of all other limited bonded
    indebtedness of the governmental entity, when added to the principal balance
    under any financing agreement or agreements of the governmental entity must not
    exceed the amount of the governmental entityâ€™s constitutional debt limit unless
    this bonded indebtedness is approved by a majority of the electors voting on
    the bonded indebtedness in a referendum duly called for this purpose by the
    governmental entity. This requirement applies notwithstanding any other
  provision of any bond act and is in addition to the terms and conditions
  specified in any bond act.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  11-27-110(C) (Supp. 2007) (emphasis added).

[4] This definition may be found at http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/operating-expenses.html. 
[5]Â Section 12-37-251(A) (2000) was amended by Act No.
  388, 2006 S.C. Acts 3138. 
[6]Â Section 6-1-320(A) provides in relevant part:

	(A)  Notwithstanding Section
  12-37-251(E) a local governing body may increase the millage rate imposed for
	general
    operating purposes above the rate imposed for such purposes for the
  preceding tax year only to the extent of the increase in the average of the
  twelve monthly consumer price indices for the most recent twelve-month period
  consisting of January through December of the preceding calendar year, plus,
  beginning in 2007, the percentage increase in the previous year in the
  population of the entity as determined by the Office of Research and Statistics
  of the State Budget and Control Board.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  6-1-320(A) (Supp. 2007) (emphasis added).
[7]Â In a recent amendment, the General Assembly provided for the suspension of the limitation upon millage rate increases for such purposes as the purchase of capital equipment
  and the purchase of undeveloped real property or of the residential development
  rights.Â  This amendment became effective
  on June 25, 2008.Â  Act No. 410, 2008 S.C. Acts 4024.Â  Thus, we recognize the
  Department did not have the benefit of this amendment at the time it issued its
  decision.Â  Because our role is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the
  General Assembly, we believe it is essential to consider this recent amendment in
  our attempt to discern what the General Assembly meant by the phrase â€œschool
  operating purposesâ€ given it is not defined in our code of laws. 
[8]Â Section 6-1-320(D) provides in pertinent part:

	The restriction contained in this section does not
  affect millage that is levied to pay bonded indebtedness or payments for real
  property purchased using a lease-purchase agreement or used to maintain
  a reserve account. Nothing in this section prohibits the use of energy-saving
  performance contracts as provided in Section 48-52-670.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-1-320(D)
  (Supp. 2007) (emphasis added).
[9]Â We respectfully disagree with the dissentâ€™s position
  which advocates a denial of tier-three reimbursements to the Plaintiffs.Â  In
  order to adopt such a decision, we believe is to essentially ignore our
  jurisprudence regarding general obligation debt.Â  Moreover, we decline to
  discount the extensive and significant legislative history of the statutes at
  issue in this case.
[10] 2006 Act No. 388, Pt. I, Â§4.C.
[11] 2006 Act No. 388, Pt. I, Â§3.
[12] Colleton Cty Taxpayers Assâ€™n v. School Dist. of
  Colleton Cty., 371 S.C. 224, 638 S.E.2d 685 (2006).
[13] This Fund, created by 2006 Act No. 388, Pt. I, Â§2. is
  essentially the successor to the Trust Fund.
[14] S.C. Const.
  art. X, Â§ 15 (stating that â€œthe governing body of any school district may incur
  general obligation debt in an amount not exceeding eight percent of the
  assessed value of all taxable property of such school districtâ€ but to exceed
  the eight percent general obligation debt limit the school district must first
  receive the approval of â€œa majority vote of the qualified electors of the school
  district voting in a referendum authorized by lawâ€).Â Â  
[15] The South Carolina General Assembly knows how
  to write an unqualified property exemption.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  12-37-250 (Supp. 2008) (providing an unqualified homestead tax exemption for
  taxpayers sixty-five and older, among others).Â  Section 12-37-220(B)(47)(a)Â  is
  a qualified statutory exemption.
[16] Lexington County School District No. 1 levied
  and collected the taxes.Â  Lexington County School District No. 4 levied, but
  did not collect, the taxes because its collection of sales tax revenue under
  the Lexington County School District Property Tax Relief Act, Act No. 378, 2004
  S.C. Acts 3142, was sufficient to make the lease-purchase payments.

The
  Supreme Court of South Carolina

	
		
			
				Jack R.
      Bennett, Respondent,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ORDER

The opinion previously filed in this
  matter on June 1, 2009 is hereby withdrawn, and the attached opinion is substituted
  in its place. 
IT IS SO ORDERED.

  
    
    
      s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
        
        s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
        
        s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.s/Donald W. Beatty                            J.
        s/John W. Kittredge                           J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
July 13, 2009

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Jack R.
      Bennett, Respondent,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26658
Submitted March 18, 2009 - Re-filed July
  13, 2009Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Karen
  Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Division
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, and Susannah Conyers Ross, of Ross &
  Enderlin, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, we granted a writ of certiorari to
  review the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s grant of
  Respondent Jack Randall Bennettâ€™s request for relief. Â The State argues that
  the PCR court erred in ruling that Respondent
  received ineffective assistance of trial counsel and appellate counsel. Â We
  find that Respondentâ€™s trial counsel and appellate counsel were not ineffective
  and reverse the PCR courtâ€™s grant of relief.Â  
Facts/Procedural History
On the evening of October 13, 1998, Respondent was at
  the home of Robert Garland (the Victim) in Marietta, South Carolina.Â  Also
  present were Lisa Ward (Ms. Ward) and Respondentâ€™s wife, Elizabeth Bennett (Ms.
  Bennett).Â  Respondent and the Victim drank large quantities of beer and
  moonshine throughout the evening.Â  Additionally, Respondent admits to ingesting
  multiple Valium pills.Â  During the course of the evening, Respondent became
  violent with Ms. Bennett.Â  The Victim and Ms. Ward ejected Respondent from the
  home.Â  Breaking through the front door, Respondent re-entered the Victimâ€™s home
  and beat him severely.
In January 2001, Respondent was tried for assault and
  battery with intent to kill (ABWIK), possession of a weapon during the
  commission of a violent crime, and first-degree burglary.Â  Ms. Bennett was not
  present for the trial but the trial court admitted her out-of-court
  statements.Â  
Ms. Ward testified that while Respondent was
  assaulting the Victim, Ms. Bennett hysterically screamed, â€œHeâ€™s going to kill
  me.â€Â  Trial counsel objected to the admission of the statement on hearsay
  grounds.Â  The trial judge ruled that Ms. Bennettâ€™s statement was an excited
  utterance, and thus admissible as an exception to the rule excluding hearsay
  testimony.Â  Ms. Ward continued her testimony stating that as the two women were
  exiting the home, Ms. Bennett screamed, â€œ[p]lease hurry, please hurry, because
  if he gets hold of me, heâ€™s going to kill me.â€Â  Trial counsel did not renew his
  objection.
Next, the State presented Officer Keith Morecraft to
  read into evidence a statement he took from Ms. Bennett at the crime scene
  ninety (90) minutes to two hours after the crime had occurred.Â  Trial counsel
  objected on both hearsay and Confrontation Clause grounds.Â  The trial court
  overruled the objection and allowed Officer Morecraft to read the statement
  into evidence.
The jury found Respondent guilty and sentenced him to
  concurrent terms of eighteen (18) years for ABWIK, five (5) years for
  possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime, and eighteen
  (18) years for first-degree burglary.Â  Appellate counsel filed an appeal
  pursuant to Anders,[1] which the court of appeals dismissed.Â  State v. Bennett, Op. No.
  2002-UP-452 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 20, 2002).Â  Respondent filed an
  application for PCR.Â  After a hearing, the PCR court granted Respondentâ€™s
  request for relief.Â  The PCR court found that trial counsel provided Respondent
  with ineffective assistance in failing to adequately object to the admission of
  Ms. Bennettâ€™s out-of-court statements.Â  The PCR court also found that appellate
  counsel provided Respondent with ineffective assistance in failing to brief
  issues concerning the admission of Ms. Bennettâ€™s out-of-court statements.[2]Â  

Standard of Review
In
  post-conviction relief proceedings, the burden of proof is on the applicant to
  prove the allegations in his application.Â  Butler v. State, 286
  S.C. 441, 442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985).Â  If the PCR courtâ€™s finding is
  supported by any evidence of probative value in the record, it should be
  upheld.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626
  (1989).Â  
Law/Analysis
The
  State argues the PCR court erred in granting relief on the grounds that trial
  counsel and appellate counsel provided ineffective assistance to Respondent.Â 
  We agree.
For
  an applicant to be granted post-conviction relief as a result of ineffective
  assistance of counsel, the applicant must show that 1) counselâ€™s performance
  was deficient,[3] and 2) he was prejudiced by counselâ€™s deficient performance.[4]Â  See Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 104 S.Ct. 2052 (1984); Porter
    v. State, 368 S.C. 378, 383, 629 S.E.2d 353, 356 (2006).Â  
I.  Trial Counsel
The State argues that the PCR court erred in finding
  trial counsel ineffective.Â  We agree.Â  
We find that trial counselâ€™s performance was not
  deficient and, therefore, his assistance was not ineffective.Â  Trial counsel
  clearly objected on hearsay grounds to the admission of Ms. Wardâ€™s testimony
  concerning Ms. Bennettâ€™s out-of-court statement.Â  The trial court correctly
  ruled that the statements were admissible as excited utterances and overruled
  trial counselâ€™s objection.[5]Â 
  Trial counselâ€™s decision not to renew his objection to Ms. Wardâ€™s continuing
  testimony as to Ms. Bennettâ€™s out-of-court statements did not constitute
  deficient assistance.Â  The second statement offered by Ms. Ward was essentially
  identical to the first; therefore, because the trial court had already ruled on
  the issue, it was not necessary for trial counsel to renew his objection.Â  See
    State v. McDaniel, 320 S.C. 33, 37, 462 S.E.2d 882, 884 (Ct. App. 1995)
  (â€œso long as the judge had an opportunity to rule on an issue, and did so, it
  was not incumbent upon defense counsel to harass the judge by parading the
  issue before him again.â€).
Additionally, trial counsel clearly objected to the
  admission of Ms. Bennettâ€™s out-of-court statement given to Officer Morecraft.Â 
  Trial counsel made this objection on multiple relevant grounds and argued it
  forcefully.Â  Because trial counsel unmistakably represented the interests of
  his client on this issue, his performance was not deficient. 
We find that there is no evidence of probative value
  in the record to support the PCR courtâ€™s finding that trial counselâ€™s
  performance was deficient.Â  Therefore, with respect to the PCR courtâ€™s grant of
  Respondentâ€™s requested relief on the grounds of ineffective assistance of trial
  counsel, we reverse. 
II.  Appellate Counsel
The State argues that the PCR court erred in finding
  appellate counsel ineffective.Â  We agree.Â  
A criminal defendant is constitutionally entitled to
  the effective assistance of appellate counsel.Â  Evitts v. Lucey, 469 U.S. 387, 398 (1985).Â  However, counsel is not required to raise every non-frivolous claim,
  but may select among them in order to maximize the likelihood of a favorable
  outcome.Â  Smith v. Robbins, 528 U.S. 259, 288 (2000).Â  
Generally, in analyzing a claim of ineffective assistance
  of appellate counsel, this Court applies the Strickland test just as it
  would when analyzing a claim of ineffective assistance of trial counsel.[6] Â See Southerland v. State, 337 S.C. 610, 616, 524 S.E.2d 833, 836
  (1999).Â  Thus, in this case, we ask 1) whether appellate counselâ€™s performance
  was deficient, and 2) whether Respondent was prejudiced by appellate counselâ€™s
  deficient performance.Â  
Even if appellate counselâ€™s performance was deficient,
  we find that such performance did not prejudice Respondent.Â  In order to show
  that he was prejudiced by appellate counselâ€™s performance, a PCR applicant must
  show that â€œthere is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s
  unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would have been
  different.â€Â  Cherry, 300 S.C. at 117-18, 386 S.E.2d at 625.Â  Ms.
  Bennettâ€™s out-of-court statements admitted at trial were cumulative evidence
  and not necessary to prove Respondentâ€™s guilt. Â Appellate counselâ€™s performance
  did not prejudice Respondent and was, therefore, not ineffective.Â  
Accordingly, we find that the PCR court erred in
  finding that Respondent received ineffective assistance of appellate counsel.Â  

CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the PCR court erred
  in ruling that trial counsel and appellate counsel were ineffective, and we
  reverse the PCR courtâ€™s order granting relief.Â Â Â  
WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Pursuant to Anders v. California, â€œif
  [appellate] counsel finds his case to be wholly frivolous, after a
  conscientious examination of it, he should so advise the court and request
  permission to withdraw.â€Â  386 U.S. 738, 744 (1967). 
[2] The issue appellate counsel briefed in the Anders appeal was unrelated to the admission of Ms. Bennettâ€™s out-of-court statements.Â  
[3] In order to prove that counselâ€™s performance was
  deficient, an applicant must show that his counsel failed to render reasonably
  effective assistance under prevailing professional norms. Â Cherry v. State,
  300 S.C. at 117-18, 386 S.E.2d at 625.
[4]Â  In order to prove that he was prejudiced by his
  counselâ€™s deficiency, an applicant must show that â€œthere is a reasonable
  probability that, but for counselâ€™s unprofessional errors, the result of the
  proceeding would have been different.â€Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115,
  117-18, 386 S.E.2d 624, 625 (1989). Â â€œA reasonable probability is a probability
  sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome of trial.â€Â  Johnson v.
    State, 325 S.C. 182, 186, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).Â Â Â  
[5] Additionally, Respondentâ€™s own defense that he was
  entering the home to protect Ms. Bennett opened the door to these statements.
[6] Appellate counsel filed an Anders brief,
  as opposed to a brief on the merits.Â  Even in this context, when analyzing a
  claim of ineffective assistance of appellate counsel, we apply the Strickland test.Â  See Smith v. Robbins, 528 U.S. 259, 284 (2000) (finding that
  even where appellate counsel believes his clientâ€™s appeal is without merit and
  thus files an Anders brief, the appellant may have been entitled to a
  merits brief and the challenge of appellate counselâ€™s performance should be
  reviewed under Stickland.)Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â

JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  This Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
After

In February 2005, a

  Respondent indicated that he was currently taking medication for hypertension

After the
  introductory questions of the plea colloquy, the judge informed Respondent of

After admitting his

The solicitor then

	On July
  4th of 2004, [Respondent] put hair grease on his penis and on the victimâ€™s
  vagina and attempted to have sexual intercourse with her.Â  When he was unable
  to do so he then penetrated her vagina with his finger and her anus with his

	In May

  against theirs.Â  All these incidents occurred while the family resided at 1 Woodmont Lane in Greenville County.Â 
	
	The

Following the
  solicitorâ€™s recitation of the facts, the judge asked Respondent whether the

  guilt, but had told him â€œonly a crazy person would do something like that.â€Â

Subsequently, the
  judge sentenced Respondent to twenty years imprisonment for CSC with a minor,
  first degree and fifteen years for each count of lewd act upon a child.Â  The
  sentences were to be served concurrently.Â  
Respondent did not
  file a direct appeal of his guilty plea.Â  Eight months after the plea,
  Respondent filed an application for PCR.Â  In his application, Respondent
  requested relief on the following grounds:Â  prosecutorial misconduct,
  ineffective assistance of counsel, and the plea courtâ€™s lack of subject matter
  jurisdiction.Â  In an amended application filed by his PCR counsel, Respondent
  asserted the following additional grounds for relief:Â  his plea was not
  knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently made; his plea counsel did not make
  him aware of the â€œnature and crucial elements of the charge against himâ€; at the
  time of the plea he was under the influence of prescribed mental health
  medications that affected his ability to comprehend what he was doing; and his

On March 1, 2007,
  the circuit court held a hearing on Respondentâ€™s PCR application.Â  At the start
  of the proceeding, Respondentâ€™s counsel outlined Respondentâ€™s bases for his
  request for PCR.Â  Counsel primarily focused her argument on Respondentâ€™s
  allegations of ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  
Specifically,
  PCR counsel alleged that plea counsel was ineffective in the following
  respects:Â  (1) he failed to bring to the courtâ€™s attention Respondentâ€™s mental
  health issues, particularly the fact that Respondent was housed in the mental
  health section of the Greenville County detention center for nine months prior
  to the plea proceeding and was taking â€œantipsychoticâ€ medication; (2) he failed
  to evaluate the Stateâ€™s evidence in that he did not make a discovery request
  and he did not view the physical evidence or the â€œrape kitâ€; and (3) he failed
  to offer any mitigation evidence, such as the lack of physical evidence, the
  absence of the victims at the plea proceeding, the Respondentâ€™s lack of a prior
  record, and the Respondentâ€™s twelve-year military history.Â  Additionally, PCR
  counsel emphasized that Respondentâ€™s plea counsel failed to review the meaning
  of â€œsexual batteryâ€ with Respondent prior to the plea.Â  Counsel asserted that
  the failure to review a crucial element of the offense was particularly
  significant given Respondentâ€™s competency was in question. 
PCR counsel then
  called Respondent as a witness. Â Respondent testified that he met with plea
  counsel only once, the day of the plea proceeding, for a ten-minute
  consultation.Â  He further stated that plea counsel never provided or reviewed
  discovery with him.Â  Because he did not review any discovery materials,
  Respondent claimed he was unaware of the SLED report stating that no physical
  evidence was found on the clothing of the nine-year-old victim.Â  Although
  Respondent acknowledged that he pled guilty, he claimed that he did not
  understand the nature of the charges, particularly the meaning of â€œsexual
  battery.â€Â  Respondent stated that his plea counsel did not explain the meaning
  of this term.Â  He further testified that had he known the definition of â€œsexual
  battery,â€ he would not have pled guilty. 
Throughout
  his direct examination, Respondent repeatedly emphasized that he was unable to
  adequately comprehend the plea proceeding due to his mental health issues and
  the medications he was taking to treat these issues.Â  Respondent contended that
  he admitted to the truth of the solicitorâ€™s factual recitation at the plea
  proceeding because he lacked the ability to comprehend and adequately defend himself
  at that time. 
Although
  Respondent specifically denied committing a sexual battery on the nine-year-old
  victim, he admitted there was inappropriate touching.Â  Despite the Stateâ€™s
  assertion that Respondent admitted to committing a sexual battery during the
  family court proceeding, Respondent testified he could not recall such an
  admission.Â  Respondent acknowledged that the family courtâ€™s order included a
  treatment plan stemming from a finding of sexual abuse.Â  Respondent, however,
  noted that there was no finding of sexual battery or CSC with a minor.Â  
On
  cross-examination, Respondent maintained that he did not inform the plea judge
  of the extent of his mental health problems because the â€œpsychiatric medication
  . . . rendered [him] incompetent to speak for [himself].â€Â  Although Respondent
  acknowledged that he was aware of the plea proceeding, he contended he did not
  want to plead guilty and only did so due to his diminished â€œmental
  capabilities.â€ 
Respondentâ€™s plea
  counsel was the second and final witness to testify.Â  Counsel testified that he
  could not recall how many times he met with Respondent prior to the plea
  proceeding.Â  He did remember that â€œhe went over the materials [he] had in his
  possession.â€Â  Plea counsel explained that he did not file a discovery motion
  because the solicitor had an open file policy and he copied the solicitorâ€™s
  file.Â  Counsel, however, was not aware of the SLED report which indicated that
  there was no physical evidence found regarding the CSC with a minor offense.Â 
  Counsel testified he was aware that Respondent had gone to a family court
  hearing, but he did not appear with Respondent because he did not know about
  the hearing at the time it was conducted.Â  Plea counsel further stated that
  prior to the plea proceeding he went over the allegations with Respondent who
  told him that â€œsomething happened.â€Â  Plea counsel testified Respondent was
  evasive and remorseful but never said he was not guilty.Â  Based on this
  discussion, plea counsel was â€œsatisfied that it happenedâ€ but Respondent did
  not want to say he did it.Â  When questioned whether Respondent appeared
  confused about the plea proceeding, plea counsel explained:

	The only
  thing that I would say that heâ€”he wanted to admit without admitting that he did
  this act. Â You know.Â  He danced around it but Iâ€™m going to plead guilty.Â  You,
  know Iâ€™m going to plead guilty.Â  But, you know, when you get into specifics as
  to what he did, he would kind of be evasive but something happened.Â  And thatâ€™s
  what he told me.Â  I said, â€œWell youâ€™re going to plead guilty to it?â€Â  And he
  said, Yes. 

On cross-examination,
  plea counsel testified that at the time he was appointed he was not aware that
  Respondent was being housed in the mental health section of the Greenville County detention center.Â  He further stated that his file did not reflect that
  he had met with Respondent prior to the day of the plea hearing.Â  In terms of
  the contents of his file, plea counsel testified that he had the â€œdiscovery
  packageâ€ provided by the solicitorâ€™s office.Â  Counsel, however, acknowledged
  that this package did not include the SLED examination and he did not go to the
  law enforcement center to review the evidence.Â  Â According to plea counsel, the
  package included the family court order in which there was a finding of sexual
  abuse. Â When asked why he did not object to the solicitorâ€™s statement that
  Respondent admitted his guilt in the family court proceeding, plea counsel
  stated, â€œTo me itâ€™s all the same . . . sexual conduct.Â  Misconduct.Â  I didnâ€™t
  make that distinction.â€Â  When specifically questioned as to whether sexual
  abuse is the same as sexual battery, plea counsel responded â€œItâ€™s all the
  same.â€Â  
With respect to his
  pre-plea discussions with Respondent, plea counsel stated that he told
  Respondent what the allegations against him were and that Respondent understood
  the charges.Â  Plea counsel admitted that he did not discuss the SLED report,
  the rape kit, or the victimâ€™s statement.Â  Instead, counsel â€œtalked about
  [Respondent] appearing in court to plead guilty and that he was guilty.â€Â 
  Counsel believed he had enough time to go over the discovery, the plea judgeâ€™s
  questions, and whether or not Respondent wanted to plead guilty.Â  Counsel
  maintained that Respondent wanted to plead guilty.Â  
By order dated
  March 26, 2007, the PCR judge granted Respondentâ€™s application and, in turn,
  reversed and remanded his convictions for CSC with a minor, first degree and
  two counts of lewd act upon a child.Â  In so holding, the PCR judge found plea
  counsel was ineffective for failing to advise Respondent regarding the meaning
  of â€œsexual battery.â€[2]Â 
  The judge noted that plea counsel â€œadmitted that he did not review the meaning
  of sexual battery with the [Respondent] saying that lewd act and criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor are basically the same thing, messing with
  children.â€Â  Based on plea counselâ€™s testimony, the judge found counsel
  â€œdemonstrated a lack of knowledge of the nature of the crimes for which he
  represented the [Respondent].â€Â  In light of this testimony and Respondentâ€™s
  testimony, the judge concluded that plea counsel did not advise Respondent of
  â€œthe meaning of sexual battery and the significance of penetration as it
  relates to criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree.â€Â Â Â  The
  judge further found that plea counselâ€™s error was not cured by the plea
  colloquy.Â  Ultimately, the judge held that plea counselâ€™s performance fell
  below reasonable and prevailing professional norms given counsel did not advise
  Respondent of the elements of CSC with a minor and did not ensure that
  Respondent understood the nature of the offense.Â  Finally, the judge found that
  Respondent proved he was prejudiced by plea counselâ€™s deficient performance
  given Respondent demonstrated that he would have insisted on going to trial had
  he known the definition of â€œsexual battery.â€Â  
The PCR judge
  denied the Stateâ€™s motion to alter or amend the order.Â  Subsequently, this
  Court granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR
  judgeâ€™s order.Â Â Â  
DISCUSSION
The State argues the PCR judge erred in finding
  Respondent would not have pled guilty if plea counsel had explained the
  definition of a â€œsexual battery.â€Â  Because plea counsel reviewed the pending
  charges and the discovery material with Respondent prior to the plea
  proceeding, the State contends counselâ€™s failure to use the term â€œsexual
  batteryâ€ did not render counselâ€™s performance deficient.Â  Even if counselâ€™s
  performance was deficient, the State claims that Respondent did not prove
  prejudice given he had admitted his misconduct and any error was cured by the
  plea colloquy.Â  Ultimately, the State seeks a reversal of the PCR judgeâ€™s
  decision to grant Respondent a new trial on all of his convictions. 
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  â€œThere is a strong presumption that counsel rendered
  adequate assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in making
  all significant decisions in the case.â€Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372 S.C. 318,
  331, 642 S.E.2d 590, 596 (2007), cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 370 (2007).Â Â  
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he or she
  is entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  â€œIn the context of a guilty plea, the court must determine
  whether 1) counselâ€™s advice was within the range of competence demanded of
  attorneys in criminal cases- i.e. was counselâ€™s performance deficient, and 2)
  if there is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, the
  defendant would not have pled guilty.â€ Smith v. State, 369 S.C. 135,
  138, 631 S.E.2d 260, 261 (2006) (citing Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 56-58 (1985)).Â  
â€œWhen
  considering an allegation on PCR that a guilty plea was based on inaccurate
  advice of counsel, the transcript of the guilty plea hearing will be considered
  to determine whether information conveyed by the plea judge cured any possible
  error made by counsel.â€ Â Burnett v. State, 352 S.C. 589, 592, 576 S.E.2d
  144, 145 (2003).Â  â€œSpecifically, the voluntariness of a guilty plea is not
  determined by an examination of a specific inquiry made by the sentencing judge
  alone, but is determined from both the record made at the time of the entry of
  the guilty plea, and also from the record of the PCR hearing.â€ Â Roddy v.
    State, 339 S.C. 29, 31, 528 S.E.2d 418, 420 (2000).
Â â€œThis
  Court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s
  findings of fact and conclusions of law.â€Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C.
  365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  In reviewing the PCR courtâ€™s decision, an appellate court is concerned
  only with whether any evidence of probative value exists to support that
  decision.  Smith, 369 S.C. at 138, 631 S.E.2d at 261.Â  This Court
  will uphold the findings of the PCR court when there is any evidence of
  probative value to support them, and will reverse the decision of the PCR court
  when it is controlled by an error of law.  Suber v. State, 371
  S.C. 554, 558-59, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007).
Section 16-3-655 of the South Carolina Code outlines the crime of first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor as follows: Â Â â€œA person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the
  first degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with the victim who is less
  than eleven years of age.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655(1) (2003).[3]Â  
â€œSexual batteryâ€ means â€œsexual
  intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio, anal intercourse, or any intrusion, however
  slight, of any part of a personâ€™s body or of any object into the genital or
  anal openings of another personâ€™s body, except when such intrusion is
  accomplished for medically recognized treatment or diagnostic purposes.â€Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-651(h) (2003).Â  
In
  contrast to â€œsexual battery,â€ â€œsexual abuseâ€ has been defined as â€œ(a) actual or
  attempted sexual contact with a child; or (b)
  permitting, enticing, encouraging, forcing, or otherwise facilitating a childâ€™s
  participation in prostitution or in a live performance or photographic representation
  of sexual activity or sexually explicit nudity; by any person including, but
  not limited to, a person responsible for the childâ€™s welfare, as defined in
  Section 20-7-490(5).â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-135(B)(2) (2003 & Supp.
  2008).
The
  term â€œsexual abuseâ€ has been used to generally describe conduct which
  precipitates a charge of CSC with a minor.Â  See, e.g., State v.
    Ladner, 373 S.C. 103, 644 S.E.2d 684 (2007) (affirming conviction for
  first-degree CSC with a minor and discussing victimâ€™s statement and medical
  evidence indicating victimâ€™s injuries were consistent with sexual abuse).Â  This
  general use, however, has never equated â€œsexual abuseâ€ with â€œsexual battery.â€Â  
Clearly, a severe incident of child sexual abuse may constitute a
  â€œsexual batteryâ€ and, in turn, CSC with a minor.Â  However, one who sexually
  abuses a child is not necessarily guilty of CSC with a minor.Â  For example, an
  inappropriate touching of a child without penetration of the childâ€™s â€œgenital
  or anal openingsâ€ would constitute sexual abuse, but would not necessarily rise
  to the level of a â€œsexual batteryâ€ and a charge of CSC with a minor.Â  Instead,
  such sexual abuse would warrant a charge of lewd act upon a child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-15-140 (2003) (â€œIt is unlawful for a person over the age of
  fourteen years to wilfully and lewdly commit or attempt a lewd or lascivious
  act upon or with the body, or its parts, of a child under the age of sixteen
  years, with the intent of arousing, appealing to, or gratifying the lust or passions
  or sexual desires of the person or of the child.â€).Â  Thus, the terms â€œsexual
  abuseâ€ and â€œsexual batteryâ€ are not synonymous.
In the instant case, plea counsel testified at the PCR hearing
  that he believed the terms were the same.Â  Because plea counsel did not
  differentiate between the two terms or correctly explain them to Respondent,
  there is evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s decision that plea counselâ€™s
  performance was deficient.Â  Given plea counsel did not comprehend this
  distinction and did not inform Respondent of a crucial element of the offense
  of CSC with a minor, first degree, we agree with the PCR judge that counselâ€™s
  representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness.Â  
We find, however, plea counselâ€™s deficient performance was cured
  by the plea colloquy even though there was no specific discussion of the term
  â€œsexual battery.â€Â  Notably, the PCR judge found that any allegations regarding
  Respondentâ€™s competency were not meritorious.Â  In light of this decision, the
  PCR judge implicitly found that Respondent had the requisite mental capacity to
  comprehend the plea proceeding.Â  
At the plea proceeding, the judge read the indictments and
  Respondent acknowledged that he understood these charges.Â  The indictment for
  CSC with a minor, first degree identified the elements of the offense which
  included a reference to a â€œsexual battery.â€Â Â  After Respondent affirmatively
  stated that he understood the charges and admitted his guilt, the solicitor
  gave a detailed factual basis for the charges.Â  In his factual recitation, the
  solicitor identified conduct which would constitute the elements of
  first-degree CSC with a minor.Â Â  Specifically, the solicitor conveyed that
  Respondent had penetrated the nine-year-old victimâ€™s vagina with his finger and
  her anus with his penis.Â  Both of these acts clearly meet the definition of a
  â€œsexual battery.â€Â  Respondent admitted that the solicitorâ€™s statement of facts
  was true.Â  Therefore, we find Respondent knowingly and voluntarily entered a
  plea as to the charge of CSC with a minor, first degree.Â  See Roddy,
  339 S.C. at 33-34, 528 S.E.2d at 421 (recognizing that for a guilty plea to be
  voluntarily and knowingly entered into, the record must establish the defendant
  had a full understanding of the consequences of his plea and the charges
  against him (citing Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238 (1969)).
In
  view of our decision, we further conclude the PCR judge erred in granting
  Respondent a new trial for the two counts of lewd act upon a child.Â  As
  previously stated, the PCR judgeâ€™s primary reason for granting Respondentâ€™s
  petition for relief was plea counselâ€™s failure to correctly inform Respondent
  of â€œsexual battery,â€ an element of CSC with a minor, first degree.Â  Given a
  â€œsexual batteryâ€ is not an element of lewd act upon a child and Respondent
  admitted to inappropriately touching his stepdaughters, the two charges for
  lewd act upon a child should not have been affected by plea counselâ€™s deficient
  performance with regard to the definition of a â€œsexual battery.â€Â  Accordingly,
  we find there is no evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s decision to grant
  Respondentâ€™s relief on these two convictions.
CONCLUSION
In
  terms of Respondentâ€™s conviction for CSC with a minor, first degree, we find
  any deficient performance by plea counsel was cured by the plea colloquy.Â  As
  to the remaining two charges, we hold there is no evidence to support the PCR
  judgeâ€™s reversal of the two counts of lewd act upon a child given any deficient
  performance by plea counsel regarding his failure to inform Respondent of the
  term â€œsexual batteryâ€ would not have affected Respondentâ€™s plea of guilty to
  the charges of lewd act upon a child.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the PCR
  judge is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
