  terms of the charge of CSC with a minor, first degree the judge informed
  Respondent that the indictment â€œalleges you did in Greenville County July 4,
  â€™04 engage in sexual battery with child-victim #3, less than eleven years of
  age.â€Â Â  
As to one of the
  charges of lewd act upon a child, the judge stated that the indictment â€œalleges
  you did in Greenville County on or about - - between June 1st and
  June 25th, â€™04 being over the age of fourteen willfully and lewdly
  committed a lewd and lascivious act upon the body or its parts of child-victim
  #2, a child under the age of sixteen with the intent of arousing, appealing to,
  gratifying the lusts, passions, or sexual desires of yourself or the child.â€Â  The
  judge reiterated this language as to the second count of lewd act upon a child
  with the exception that the date of the offense was May 31, 2004, and involved
  child-victim #1. 
[2]  The PCR judge found Respondentâ€™s remaining
  allegations of ineffective assistance of counsel, prosecutorial misconduct, and
  lack of subject matter jurisdiction to be without merit.Â  
[3]Â  Because the alleged sexual misconduct occurred in July
  2004, we cite to this version of the statute given there have been substantive
  changes made to section 16-3-655 in subsequent years.

				Appellate
  Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of

				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant

JUSTICE KITTREDGE:  As
  a result of a videotaped sting operation, Jeremiah Dicapua was convicted and
  sentenced for distribution of crack cocaine and possession with intent to
  distribute crack cocaine.Â  On the day following sentencing, the trial court sua
    sponte vacated the juryâ€™s verdict and ordered a new trial on the basis of
  perceived weaknesses in the videotape evidence, even though the tape was
  admitted without objection.Â  Moreover, the trial court ruled that the videotape
  could not be admitted in evidence in the new trial.Â  The State appealed,
  contending the sua sponte grant of a new trial constituted legal error
  warranting reversal.
Because
  Dicapua waived any direct challenge to the videotape by consenting to its
  admission, the court of appeals reversed the trial courtâ€™s sua sponte,
  new trial order and reinstated the sentence.Â  State
    v. Dicapua, 373
  S.C. 452, 455-56, 646 S.E.2d 150, 152 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  We
  granted a writ of certiorari.Â  We affirm.
I.
The Horry County
  Police Department and the Myrtle Beach Police Department conducted a drug sting
  in a hotel.Â  One hotel room was a control room where the officers observed the
  suspects and the informant.Â  The adjoining hotel room served as the transaction
  room, which was set up with separate video and audio recording devices.Â  On the
  day in question, the audio equipment malfunctioned.
The
  hotel room was initially searched by the police for drugs, and the informant
  was searched as well.Â  The informant was given one hundred and eighty dollars
  in marked money by the police.Â  The informant and another woman in the hotel
  room were arrested earlier that day for prostitution.
The informant briefly
  left the room and reentered with Dicapua.Â  The informant counted out the money
  and placed it on the bed.Â  Next, Dicapua counted the money and appeared to drop
  something on the bed.Â  The informant then placed an unknown substance in her
  pocket.Â  After the police entered the transaction room, the police searched Dicapua
  and found drugs.Â  The police also located drugs on the informant for a total of
  2.4 grams of crack cocaine.Â  Dicapua admitted the informant gave him one
  hundred and sixty dollars.
Dicapua was tried
  for and convicted of distribution of crack cocaine and possession with intent
  to distribute crack cocaine.Â  At trial, Dicapua did not object to the admission
  of the videotape.Â  Following the Stateâ€™s case, Dicapua made multiple motions:
  for a dismissal and a mistrial due to the lack of a link between the drugs
  found on the informant and Dicapua, for a directed verdict due to the â€œtotalityâ€
  of the Stateâ€™s case, and for dismissal due to entrapment.Â  Notably, these
  motions did not refer to the admission of the videotape.
Following
  the juryâ€™s guilty verdicts, Dicapua moved to set aside the verdict as there was
  no evidence Dicapua intended to sell additional drugs and â€œthe objections and
  request going back to the [informant], the chain, and all those things.â€Â  Again,
  these motions did not implicate the admission of the videotape.Â  The trial
  court sentenced Dicapua to thirty months for both charges to run concurrently.
The
  next day the trial court sua sponte ordered a new trial because of
  concerns about the videotape.Â  The trial court additionally ordered, â€œit is the
  decision of this Court to suppress the introduction of the videotape in any new
  trial to be had on the charges.â€[1]Â 
  The State served its notice of appeal.Â  The trial court subsequently held a hearing
  to supplement the record and further explain its decision.[2]
The State appealed
  the trial courtâ€™s sua sponte order.Â  The court of appeals reversed.Â  State
    v. Dicapua, 373 S.C. 452, 456, 646 S.E.2d 150, 152 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  The
  court of appeals majority found an abuse of discretion by the trial courtâ€™s
  granting of a new trial for a waived issue, the admission of the videotape.Â  Id. at 455, 646 S.E.2d at 152.Â  One panel member of the court of appeals concurred,
  addressing the matter of appealability.Â  Id. at 457, 646 S.E.2d at 153.Â 
  This Court granted Dicapuaâ€™s petition for certiorari.
II.
We first address
  the threshold matter of appealability. Â â€œThe State may only appeal a new trial
  order if, in granting it, the trial judge committed an error of law.â€Â  State
    v. Johnson, 376 S.C. 8, 10, 654 S.E.2d 835, 836 (2007).Â  To determine if an
  error of law occurred, it is necessary to examine the merits of the case.Â  Id. at 11, 654 S.E.2d at 836.Â  We find an error of law occurred when the trial court
  granted a new trial on the basis of evidence admitted with Dicapuaâ€™s consent.Â 
  Because of the error of law, the matter is appealable.
We
  now turn to the legal issue which resolves this caseâ€”may a trial court in a
  criminal case sua sponte order a new trial on a ground not raised by a
  party?Â  We answered this question â€œnoâ€ in the context of a civil proceeding in Southern Railway Co. v. Coltex, Inc., 285 S.C. 213, 214, 329 S.E.2d 736,
  736 (1985) (â€œThe sole issue is whether a trial judge ex mero motu[3] can grant a new trial on a ground not raised by a party. Â We hold he cannot.â€).[4]Â 
  We hold the same result must follow in a criminal case.[5]Â 
  Moreover, to affirm the grant of a new trial on a waived issue in a criminal
  case would lend this Courtâ€™s imprimatur to a trial courtâ€™s impromptu grant of
  post conviction relief.
By
  consenting to the admission of the videotape evidence, Dicapua waived any
  direct challenge to the admission of the evidence.Â  Concomitantly, the trial
  court lacked authority to grant relief on the basis of a ground not raised by
  Dicapua.Â  We hold the granting of a new trial sua sponte on a ground waived
  by a party is an error of law.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1]  Counsel
  for Dicapua conceded at oral argument that it was error to preemptively
  suppress the videotape at a new trial.
[2]  Because
  the filing of the appeal deprived the trial court of jurisdiction, we may not
  consider the trial courtâ€™s post-appeal explanation.
[3]  Ex
  mero motu is a synonymn for sua sponte.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 596
  (7th ed. 1999).
[4]  As in the case at hand, in Southern Railway, Southern waived the ground
  on which the trial court sua sponte granted a new trial.Â  285 S.C. at 215-16, 329 S.E.2d at 737-38.Â 
  Specifically, the trial court in Southern Railway stated that â€œ[t]his new trial is not granted on the
  grounds as contended by [Southern] . . . .â€ Â Id. at 215, 329 S.E.2d 737.
  Â In reversing the sua sponte grant of a new trial, we held â€œSouthern
  waived the right to claim the omitted charge was error by not objecting to its
  omission at the trial level.Â  Therefore, the omitted charge was not properly
  before the trial court, the Court of Appeals, or this Court.â€ Â Id. at 216, 329 S.E.2d at 737-38.
[5]  We
  acknowledge Rule 59(d), SCRCP, allows a civil trial court to order a new trial
  within ten days of the entry of judgment for â€œany reason for which [the trial
  court] might have granted a new trial on motion of a party.â€Â  We further
  acknowledge that when a civil trial court exercises its
  discretionary right to sit as a thirteenth juror and grants a new trial when
  the verdict is contrary to the evidence, its decision will be upheld if
  there is any evidence to support it. Â Southern Railway, 285
  S.C. at 216, 329 S.E.2d at 738.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Ken Buffington,
      Louis Shepard, Mary E. Williams, Brian Meece and Shirley Jones, Respondents,
				v.
				T.O.E.
      Enterprises, A South Carolina General Partnership and T.O.E. Residential,
      LLC, Petitioners.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Pickens County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26685
Heard April 22, 2009 - Filed July 13, 2009 
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				W.
  Grady Jordan, of Olson, Smith, Jordan & Cox, of Easley, for Petitioners.
				J.
  J Wilkes, of Greenville, for Respondents.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Respondents filed an
  action seeking a declaratory judgment that in using their land for commercial
  purposes, Petitioners were acting in violation of the restrictive covenants.Â 
  The trial court found that Petitioners were in violation of the covenants and
  issued an injunction prohibiting Petitioners from using two lots for commercial
  purposes.Â  The court of appeals affirmed, Buffington v. T.O.E. Enters.,
  Op. No. 2007-UP-252 (S.C. Ct. App. filed May 24, 2007), and this Court granted
  a writ of certiorari to review that decision.Â  We affirm as modified. 
Factual/Procedural
  Background
Forest Acres is a subdivision located in Easley, South
  Carolina, which was developed in 1958.Â  The restrictive covenants provide that, â€œ[n]o lot shall be used except for
  residential purposes,â€ but the covenants only apply to 62 of the 110 lots of
  the subdivision. Â Respondents own lots in Forest Acres, and Petitioners
  operate a Toyota dealership that borders the subdivision.Â  In 2003 and 2004,
  Petitioners purchased lots 9, 10, 11, and 12 located across from the dealership
  and within the subdivision.Â  Petitioners intended for the lots to be used for
  additional parking and began developing the land.Â  


Respondents
  brought an action seeking to enjoin Petitioners from using lots 9, 10, and 12[1] for commercial purposes.Â  The trial court found that lots 10 and 12 were
  subject to the restrictive covenants and thus could only be used for
  residential purposes.[2]Â 
  The trial court ruled that Petitioners failed to show that they were entitled
  to use the property for commercial purposes under an equity theory and that
  Petitioners failed to show that a change of conditions 

existed to warrant the
  release of the restrictive covenants.Â  Accordingly, the trial court issued an
  injunction prohibiting Petitioners from using the land for parking purposes.Â  The
  court of appeals affirmed.

	We granted a writ of certiorari to
  review the following issue:[3]
	Did the court of appeals err
  in holding that a court is not required to balance the equities before
  enforcing a restrictive covenant, but that even if it were to balance the
  equities, equity favored enforcement?

Standard of Review
An action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is
  an action in equity. Â South Carolina Depâ€™t of
    Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345
  S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001). Â On appeal from an equitable action, an appellate court may find
  facts in accordance with its own view of the evidence. Â Townes Assoc. v.
    City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â Â  While
  this standard permits a broad scope of review, an appellate court will not
  disregard the findings of the trial court, which saw and heard the witnesses
  and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301
  S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1990).
Law/Analysis
Petitioners
  argue that the court of appeals erred in holding that
  the equities favored the enforcement of the restrictive covenants.Â 
  Respondents, on the other hand, argue that a court is not required to balance
  the equities in deciding whether to enforce restrictive covenants, but regardless,
  the equities favor enforcement.Â  
A restriction on the use of the property must be created in
  express terms or by plain and unmistakable implication, and all such
  restrictions are to be strictly construed, with all doubts resolved in favor of
  the free use of property.Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369
  S.C. 160, 166, 631 S.E.2d 539, 542 (2006).Â 
  Thus, courts tend to strictly interpret restrictive covenants, and to enforce a
  restrictive covenant, a party must show that the restriction applies to the property
  either by the covenantâ€™s express language or by a plain and unmistakable
  implication.Â  Id.; Sea Pines Plantation Co. v. Wells, 294 S.C.
  266, 269, 363 S.E.2d 891, 894 (1987).Â  
We
  first address whether courts must balance the equities in determining whether
  to enforce a restrictive covenant.Â  In affirming the trial courtâ€™s injunction
  against Petitioners, the court of appeals stated that, pursuant to Siau v. Kassel,
  369 S.C. 631, 641, 632 S.E.2d 888, 893 (Ct. App. 2006) and Houck v. Rivers,
  316 S.C. 414, 418, 450 S.E.2d 106, 109 (Ct. App. 1994), once the court
  finds that a restrictive covenant has been violated, it is not required to balance the equities of the
  parties before enforcing a covenant.Â  However, a review of this Courtâ€™s
  decisions on this issue reveals that this statement is contrary to our
  precedent.Â  
In Circle Square Co. v. Atlantis Dev. Co., 267 S.C. 618, 230 S.E.2d 704 (1976), the Court first determined that the
  defendantâ€™s proposed use of the land violated the restrictive covenants and
  then held that the plaintiffs were not barred from seeking an injunction pursuant
  to laches, waiver, or estoppel.Â  In Rabon v. Mali,
  289 S.C. 37, 344 S.E.2d 608 (1986), this Court engaged in an equitable analysis
  and found that the defendant established laches as a defense to using his land
  for commercial purposes in violation of the restrictive covenants.Â  Finally, in Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas Horizontal Prop. Regime, 307 S.C. 339, 415 S.E.2d 384 (1992),
  the Court held that although the trial court erred in allowing the homeowners
  to offensively assert equitable defenses, the homeowners still prevailed under
  equitable considerations and thus the restrictive covenants could not be
  enforced against them.Â  
Accordingly, while there is no formulaic balancing
  test, we find that this Court has consistently held that
  courts should consider equitable doctrines when determining whether to enforce
  a restrictive covenant and enjoin a landowner from using their land in a manner
  that violates the covenant.Â  Indeed, an action to enforce a restrictive
  covenant is an action in equity, and to hold that a court must issue an
  injunction as a matter of law upon a finding that a restrictive covenant has
  been violated is erroneous.Â  We therefore hold that Siau and Houck are
  overruled to the extent they hold otherwise.Â  
Turning
  to the merits of this case, we hold that the restrictive covenants are
  enforceable.Â  Petitioners admitted that using the land for parking violated the
  restriction that the land may only be used for residential purposes.Â  However,
  Petitioners testified that they have expended over $700,000 on improvements to
  the land, that Toyota will require them to relocate if they are not able to
  expand the business, and that using the lot for commercial purposes will not
  negatively impact Respondentsâ€™ property value since lots 10 and 12 are located
  between unrestricted lots and other businesses are located in close proximity
  to the lots.Â  Respondents testified that
  the commercial development of Lots 10 and 12 created additional light and noise
  pollution and adversely affected their property values.Â  
We
  find that the Petitioner cannot prevail under an equity theory.Â  In our view,
  it would be inequitable to consider Petitionersâ€™ financial loss in purchasing
  and improving the land since they were on notice of the covenants when they
  purchased the property. Â To find
  otherwise would indicate that any business could defeat a restrictive covenant
  by spending a significant amount of money developing the land.Â  Moreover, Petitioners
  cannot show that Respondents have waived their rights or that Respondents may
  be estopped from enforcing the covenants.Â  The lots have never been used for
  commercial purposes, and Respondents brought suit as soon as Petitioners began
  developing the lots.Â  The record contains no evidence to support lifting the
  covenants based on equitable doctrines.Â  In our view, to ignore the restrictive
  covenants in the absence of such evidence would eliminate a homeownerâ€™s
  justified reliance on property restrictions.Â  Therefore, we find that equity
  does not weigh in Petitionersâ€™ favor and the restrictive covenants are
  enforceable.[4]
Accordingly, we hold that, upon a finding
  that a restrictive covenant has been violated, a court may not enforce the
  restrictive covenant as a matter of law.Â  Rather, the court must consider
  equitable doctrines asserted by a party when deciding whether to enforce the
  covenant.Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the court of
  appealsâ€™ decision as modified.Â  
WALLER,
  PLEICONES, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James R. Barber, concur.


[1] Lot 11 is not subject to the restrictive covenants.
[2] The trial court found that lot 9 was not subject to the restrictive covenants.Â 
  Respondents did not appeal this ruling.
[3] We denied certiorari to review the change of circumstances issue.Â Â  
[4] Because we denied certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision as to
  changed conditions, we are not considering facts and arguments related to that
  issue in deciding this case.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of David Arthur Braghirol, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No.Â  26686
Heard June 10, 2009 - Filed July 13, 2009Â  
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Lesley M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Ericka M. Williams,
  Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of
  Disciplinary Counsel.
				David Arthur Braghirol, of Columbia, pro se.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, the
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) filed three separate sets of formal
  charges against respondent, David
  Arthur Braghirol.Â  After two hearings, the
  Panel recommended that respondent be suspended from the practice of law for six
  months, with conditions, and be required to pay the costs of the proceedings. Â We
  agree a definite suspension, with conditions, is the appropriate sanction, but
  we impose a nine-month suspension. 

PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The
  first two sets of formal charges were filed in November 2007 and February 2008;
  these charges represent three separate matters.Â  Respondent failed to answer
  the charges, and default orders were entered.Â  On May 29, 2008, a hearing was
  held before the Panel; respondent appeared and made a statement in mitigation.Â  
Respondent
  was placed on interim suspension on June 24, 2008.Â  On June 26, 2008, ODC filed
  the third set of charges regarding two additional matters.Â  Respondent again
  failed to respond and was held in default.Â  The Panel held a second hearing on
  October 28, 2008, and subsequently issued its report finding that respondent
  had violated various Rules of Professional Conduct.Â  The Panel recommended that
  respondent be definitely suspended for six months, retroactive to his interim
  suspension date of June 24, 2008.Â  Additionally, the Panel recommended that
  respondent:

	
		be ordered to pay the award from
  the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board;
 
		 be required to work with a South Carolina attorney serving as respondentâ€™s mentor for 24 months;[1]
 
		be required to seek psychological
  counseling, at his own expense, for 24 months, and submit quarterly updates
  from the psychologist to the Office of Commission Counsel;
 
		make appropriate restitution to
  complainants; and
 
		be ordered to pay the costs of the
  disciplinary proceedings.
	

ODC
  objects to the six-month suspension and requests a definite suspension for a
  longer time period.[2]Â Â Â  
FACTS
The formal
  charges alleged five separate matters.Â  We also note the various mitigating and
  aggravating circumstances of this case, as well as respondentâ€™s prior
  disciplinary history.
1.Â  Wren Matter
Respondent
  was appointed to represent complainant Wren in a criminal matter.Â  He attended
  a preliminary hearing at which respondent told Wren he would return within a
  day or two to meet with him.Â  Respondent, however, failed to meet with Wren or
  contact him after the preliminary hearing.Â  Wren wrote to respondent on three
  separate occasions inquiring about the status of his case.Â  Respondent failed
  to respond to Wren.
Respondent
  was notified by the Solicitorâ€™s Office that Wrenâ€™s case was dismissed on August
  4, 2006.Â  Respondent failed to notify Wren about the August 2006 dismissal.Â 
  There was, however, an error in Wrenâ€™s discharging paperwork, and Wren remained
  incarcerated until April 2007, unaware that his criminal charges had been
  dismissed approximately eight months earlier.Â  Respondent failed to recognize
  the error with the discharging paperwork or take any action to correct the
  error until a copy of Wrenâ€™s complaint was mailed to respondent by ODC in April 2007.
Additionally, respondent failed to respond to ODCâ€™s
  initial inquiries about this matter, and he failed to respond to the notice of
  full investigation subsequently served upon him.
2.Â  Fee Dispute Matter
The South Carolina
  Bar Resolution of Fee Disputes Board (â€œBoardâ€) ordered respondent to pay
  $500.00 to a former client.Â  Respondent failed to comply with the order of the
  Board.Â  As a result, the Board issued respondent a Certificate of
  Non-Compliance and sent a copy to ODC on August 7, 2007.
Respondent failed
  to respond to ODCâ€™s repeated inquiries about this matter, and he failed to
  respond to the notice of full investigation subsequently served upon him.Â  As
  of the May 2008 hearing, respondent still had not paid the award as ordered by
  the Board.
3.Â  Sheppard Matter
On
  September 10, 2007, respondent requested the production of a criminal trial
  transcript from a court reporter.Â  On September 21, 2007, the court reporter
  notified respondent that the transcript was complete and mailed an invoice for
  $229.25.Â  In October and November 2007, the court reporter mailed respondent
  overdue notices.Â  In addition, the court reporter left telephone messages with
  respondent.Â  On November 30, 2007, South Carolina Court Administration mailed
  respondent a letter advising respondent of his overdue court reporter invoice.
ODC served a supplemental notice of full investigation, but respondent failed to
  respond or otherwise communicate with ODC on this matter.Â  Respondent finally paid
  the court reporter in January or February 2008.

4.Â  Isphording
  Matter
Respondent
  was retained in 2006 to represent complainant Isphording in a domestic action.Â 
  Respondent appeared at a temporary hearing in August 2007 where he was
  unprepared and failed to competently represent Isphording.Â  A child support
  hearing was scheduled for December 5, 2007.Â  Respondent called the Court three
  hours after the hearing was scheduled to begin to report that he would not be
  able to attend.Â  The hearing was continued until the following week, but
  respondent failed to appear for the rescheduled hearing.Â  He also failed to
  notify either Isphording or the court that he could not appear for the
  hearing.Â  The hearing was again continued. Respondent failed to notify
  Isphording of the rescheduled hearing and failed to attend the hearing.Â  He
  again failed to notify either Isphording or the court that he could not appear
  for the hearing.
Respondent received a notarized Financial Declaration from Isphording in
  January 2008 that he failed to submit to the court.Â  As a result, the court
  issued a child support order without the benefit of reviewing Isphordingâ€™s
  financial situation.Â  Respondent failed to notify Isphording that the court had
  issued a child support order, and a Rule to Show Cause was issued against her
  in March 2008 for failure to pay the court-ordered support.
Respondent
  failed to keep Isphording reasonably informed of the status of her case and
  refused to return her telephone calls.Â  She terminated respondentâ€™s services
  and requested that he return her complete client file, but respondent failed to
  do so and failed to refund her legal fees that were unearned by him.
Respondent
  failed to respond to ODCâ€™s supplemental notice of full
  investigation on this matter.
5.Â  Glover
  Matter
Respondent
  was retained by complainant Glover in early 2004 to initiate a civil action on
  her behalf against Table Rock Investments, LLC.Â  Respondent failed to keep
  Glover reasonably informed regarding the status of her case and failed to
  return her numerous phone calls.Â  Additionally, respondent failed to safeguard
  Gloverâ€™s property in that he informed her that he had lost all of her original
  documents.
In a
  meeting with Glover in November 2007, respondent informed her he would be
  settling her case for $5,000.00.Â  Respondent, however, has had no contact with
  Glover since then, has failed to settle her case, and has failed to notify her
  that he had not settled the case.Â  Respondent has failed to do any meaningful
  work on Gloverâ€™s case and has failed to expedite litigation consistent with her
  wishes.
Respondent
  failed to respond to ODCâ€™s supplemental notice of full
  investigation on this matter.
Mitigating
  Circumstances
At the
  May 2008 hearing, respondent testified to the Panel about his background and
  several extenuating circumstances that led to his misconduct.Â  In 2005, his
  79-year-old father committed suicide in front of his mother by using a .22
  pistol to shoot himself in the head.Â  Respondentâ€™s mother called him.Â  When he
  arrived, his mother was refusing to let EMS take the body away from her.Â 
  Respondent was the person who cleaned the blood off the walls.
Three
  days later, respondent and his wife found out she was pregnant.Â  Because of a
  miscarriage a few months prior, they soon had an ultrasound and discovered she
  was pregnant with twins.Â  Respondent described the pregnancy as â€œtumultuous.â€Â 
  The twins were born in January 2006.Â  According to respondent, his wife suffers
  from depression and experienced severe post-partum depression.Â  He stated that
  he was trying to â€œjuggleâ€ his wifeâ€™s depression, the care-taking of the twins,
  the after-effects of his fatherâ€™s suicide, the needs of his 11-year-old
  stepdaughter, and his solo practice.Â  
Some
  time after he was served the formal charges, he called his mother and requested
  that she take care of the two-year-old twins at her home.Â  Additionally, after
  he met with disciplinary counsel for an interview, he went to a physician and
  found out he had type two diabetes.Â  He was placed on medication for the
  diabetes, as well as anti-depressants.
Respondent
  also made a statement at the second hearing, which occurred in October 2008,
  approximately four months after he was placed on interim suspension.Â  He told
  the Panel that after the first hearing, he began seeing a psychiatrist.Â  He
  stated that with counseling and medication, he had â€œregained his strengthâ€ and
  he asked that he be allowed to continue to practice law.
Respondent submitted an affidavit from his treating psychiatrist,
  Dr. Steude.Â  Dr. Steude began treating respondent in August 2008 and diagnosed
  him with Major Depressive Disorder.Â  Dr. Steude stated that with medication and
  therapy, respondentâ€™s depression has gone into remission.Â  He noted respondent
  has been cooperative, interactive and honest during his treatment.Â  Dr. Steude
  opined that respondentâ€™s personal and marital issues, although not fully
  resolved, should have â€œminimal impact, if any, on his ability to competently
  practice law.â€
Aggravating
  Circumstances / Previous Disciplinary History
The Panel considered two aggravating circumstances:Â  (1)
  respondentâ€™s pattern of not responding and/or cooperating with ODC regarding these five matters; and (2) his prior disciplinary history regarding
  a finding of minor misconduct in 2006 for failure to respond which resulted in
  a letter of caution.
In addition, respondent has the following additional disciplinary
  history.Â  On February 3, 2004, respondent was suspended by the CLE Commission;
  he was reinstated on February 4, 2004.Â  On April 2, 2008, he was again
  suspended by the CLE Commission; he was reinstated on April 18, 2008.Â  He was
  placed on interim suspension on June 24, 2008.Â  On April 2, 2009, he was
  suspended by the CLE Commission.

DISCUSSION
The
  authority to discipline attorneys and the manner in which the discipline is
  given rests entirely with this Court.Â  In re McFarland, 360 S.C. 101,
  600 S.E.2d 537 (2004); In re Long, 346 S.C. 110, 551 S.E.2d 586
  (2001).Â  Under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement (RLDE), respondent
  is in default, and therefore, he is deemed to have admitted all factual
  allegations of the formal charges.Â  See Rule 24 RLDE, in Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  The charges of misconduct against respondent likewise are deemed
  admitted, and thus, the Court must only determine the appropriate sanction.Â  E.g., Matter of Thornton, 327 S.C. 193, 489 S.E.2d 198 (1997).
Based on the facts of the five matters outlined above, we find
  respondent violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct (RPC), found in
  Rule 407, SCACR:

	Rule 1.1 - Competence
 
	Rule 1.2 - Scope of
  Representation
 
	Rule 1.3 - Diligence
 
	Rule 1.4 -
  Communication 
 
	Rule 1.15(d) -
  Safekeeping of Property
 
	Rule 1.16(d) -
  Declining or Terminating Representation
 
	Rule 3.2 - Expediting
  Litigation
 
	Rule 8.1(b) - Bar Admissions
  and Disciplinary Matters
 
	Rule 8.4(a) & (e)
  - Violation of RPC and Conduct Prejudicial to the Administration of Justice

In addition, we find respondent violated Rule 7(a) of the Rules for Lawyer
  Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, including: 

	Rule 7(a)(1)
  (violating a Rule of Professional Conduct)
 
	Rule 7(a)(3) (knowingly fail to respond to a lawful demand from a
  disciplinary authority)
 
	Rule 7(a)(5) (conduct
  tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the legal
  profession into disrepute)
 
	Rule 7(a)(6) (violating the oath of office taken to practice law in South Carolina)
 
	Rule 7(a)(10) (willfully failing to comply with a final decision of
  the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board)

ODC argues that
  respondentâ€™s pattern of not responding and not cooperating with ODC, combined
  with respondentâ€™s misconduct, warrant a definite suspension of greater than six
  months.Â  We agree. Â See In re Sturkey, 376 S.C. 286, 657 S.E.2d
  465 (2008) (where attorney failed respond to charges related to eight
  matters in criminal cases, the Court imposed a nine-month definite suspension,
  with participation in a law office management program and payment of costs); In
    re Conway, 374 S.C. 75, 647 S.E.2d 235 (2007) (where attorney, inter
      alia, failed to pay court reporter, failed to safeguard client files, and
  failed to respond to charges, this Court accepted an agreement for a definite
  suspension of nine months); In re Cabaniss, 369 S.C. 216, 632 S.E.2d
  280 (2006) (where attorney inter alia neglected or performed less
  than competently on nine client matters, the Court accepted an agreement for a twelve-month
  suspension, retroactive to the date of respondent's interim suspension).
Accordingly,
  we impose a nine-month definite suspension as a sanction for respondentâ€™s
  misconduct.Â  The definite suspension shall be retroactive to respondentâ€™s
  interim suspension. Â We further impose all the additional conditions
  recommended by the Panel, i.e., restitution, as well as 24 months of mentoring
  and counseling.Â  We order respondent to pay the costs of these disciplinary
  proceedings to the Commission on Lawyer Conduct within 30 days of the date of
  this opinion.
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.Â Â  
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.



[1] The Report states that:

	The
  mentorâ€™s duties should include, at a minimum, regular meetings or interviews
  with Respondent and a monthly review of Respondentâ€™s law office practices to
  include Respondentâ€™s trust accounting and reconciliation practices.Â  Respondent
  should be responsible for submitting quarterly reports from the mentor to the
  Office of Commission Counsel for the entire twenty four (24) month period.

In addition, the Panel
  also recommended that the mentor assist respondent in preparing a list of the
  cases that he is handling so that he and the mentor could go over the list on a
  monthly basis.
[2] ODC does not object to: (1) the remaining
  recommendations by the Panel; and (2) any imposed sanction being applied
  retroactively to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.

THE
  STATE OF
  
      
  SOUTH CAROLINA
In
  The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Derwin Thomas
      Brannon, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26687
Submitted June 12, 2009 - Filed July 13, 2009Â  
DEFINITE SUSPENSION



	
		
			
				Lesley M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and Ericka
  M. Williams, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of
  
  Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Hervery B.O. Young, of
 
  Clinton,
  for respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter,
  respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an
  Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413,
  SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent
  admits misconduct and consents to any sanction within Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  He
  requests that, if the Court imposes a suspension, the suspension be made
  retroactive to April 30, 2008, the date of his interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of Brannon,
  377 S.C. 474, 661 S.E.2d 98 (2008).Â  We accept the agreement and impose a one year suspension, retroactive to
  the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Matter I
Respondent
  was retained to represent Complainant A in an automobile accident case where
  Complainant A had previously received a settlement offer of $11,000.00 from the
  insurance company.Â  Respondent failed to
  file suit prior to the expiration of the statute of limitations.Â  Respondent admits he failed to adequately
  communicate with Complainant A regarding the case both before and after the
  statute of limitations expired.Â  
By
  letter from ODC dated October 15, 2007, respondent was notified of the
  complaint in this matter.Â  He did not
  file a response withinÂ  fifteen (15) days, as requested; instead, he asked ODC for a
  fifteen (15) day extension of time in which to file a response.Â  ODC agreed to the extension, giving
  respondent until November 14, 2007, to respond to the complaint.Â  No response was received.Â  On December 11, 2007, ODC sent respondent a
  letter pursuant to In the Matter of Treacy, 277 S.C. 514, 290 S.E.2d 240
  (1982), again requesting a response.Â  Respondent
  failed to respond or otherwise communicate with ODC.Â  
On
  February 19, 2008, respondent was served with a Notice of Full Investigation
  requesting a response within thirty (30) days.Â  Respondent did not respond within thirty (30) days. Respondent filed a
  response to the Notice of Full Investigation on May 16, 2008, almost two months
  after his response was due.Â  
Matter II
In
  September 2007, Complainant B retained respondent for representation in a civil
  matter.Â  Complainant B paid respondent a
  $5,000.00 retainer fee.Â  Respondent
  admits he failed to keep Complainant B reasonably informed regarding the status
  of her case and failed to return or respond to her numerous telephone calls,
  pages, and emails.Â  
On
  October 30, 2007, respondent told Complainant B that he had not done any work
  on her case.Â  He promised to write a
  demand letter to the defendantâ€™s lawyer by the end of the week, but failed to
  do so.Â  
Respondent
  instructed his staff to cancel his November 15, 2007, appointment with
  Complainant B two hours prior to the scheduled meeting.Â  Respondentâ€™s staff promised Complainant B
  that respondent would telephone her later on November 15, 2007, after he spoke with
  defense counsel.Â  Respondent did not
  contact Complainant B on November 15, 2007, as promised, and, as of December
  12, 2007, he still had not made any contact with Complainant B.Â  
On
  February 19, 2008, respondent was served with a Notice of Full Investigation
  requesting a response within thirty (30) days.Â  Respondent failed to respond to the Notice of Full Investigation prior
  to the expiration of the thirty (30) day period.Â  Respondent filed a response on May 16, 2008,
  almost two months after his response was due.Â  Â Â 
Matter III
On
  March 19, 2008, respondent was mailed a Notice to Appear before Disciplinary
  Counsel on April 22, 2008, at 10:00 a.m., in reference to Matter I and Matter
  II.Â  He was also mailed a subpoena
  commanding him to bring client files in Matter I and Matter II.Â  
Respondent
  failed to appear on April 22, 2008, and failed to communicate with Disciplinary
  Counsel regarding his scheduled appointment.Â  Respondent also failed to produce the subpoenaed information on or
  before April 22, 2008, and, thereby, failed to comply with the subpoena. 
Matter IV
On
  April 17, 2006, respondent issued a check to a client in the amount of
  $2,500.00 as partial reimbursement of the clientâ€™s retainer fee. Â The balance in respondentâ€™s trust account
  (Account One) per the April 30, 2006 bank statement was $31,344.00.Â  
The
  following year, respondent opened a new trust account (Account Two) with a
  different bank.Â  Other than allowing
  outstanding checks to clear Account One, respondent ceased using Account One
  and began using Account Two as his active trust account.Â  The client attempted to cash the check
  written on Account One, but was unable to cash the check due to insufficient
  funds in Account One.Â  Respondent admits
  he failed to maintain an accurate accounting and financial record of the funds
  remaining in Account One and that he failed to properly reconcile his account
  to insure that sufficient funds remained in Account One to satisfy all
  outstanding checks written on that account.Â  
LAW
Respondent
  admits that by his conduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules
  of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to client); Rule
  1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing
  client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of
  matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 3.2
  (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to expedite litigation consistent with
  the interests of client); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safeguard client funds); Rule
  8.1(b) (lawyer shall not knowingly fail to respond to a lawful demand for
  information from a disciplinary authority); Â Â Â Â Â Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct
  for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional
  misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct prejudicial to administration of
  justice).Â  In addition, respondent admits
  that his actions constitute grounds for discipline under the following
  provisions of Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to
  violate the Rules of Professional Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(3) (it shall be a
  ground for discipline for a lawyer to willfully fail to appear personally as
  directed, willfully fail to comply with a subpoena issued under the RLDE, or
  knowingly fail to respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority to
  include a request for a response or appearance under Rule 19, RLDE).
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for
  Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent from the practice of law for one
  (1) year, retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  In addition, pursuant to the agreement,
  respondent shall pay the costs incurred by ODC and the Commission on Lawyer
  Conduct within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the filing of
  this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit demonstrating he has complied
  with the requirements of Rule 30 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary
  Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and
  KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Ervin
          McMillian, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Post-Conviction Relief Judge

Opinion No.Â  26688
  Submitted April 22, 2009 - Filed July 20,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate
          Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Office of Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley E. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Brian
          T. Petrano, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  Ervin
  McMillian[1] filed a petition for a writ of certiorari seeking review of an order denying
  his application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  We granted the petition to
  decide the following question:Â  Was counsel ineffective for advising McMillian
  that the intent to commit a crime could be inferred from the act of
  trespassing, such that it would provide a factual basis to support a plea to
  first-degree burglary?Â  We hold counsel was not ineffective and affirm.
FACTS
McMillian was
  charged with first-degree burglary as a result of an incident that occurred in Columbia, South Carolina on April 10, 2004.Â  At approximately 1:00 a.m. on that date,
  McMillian knocked on the door of the home of Lanelle Hicks and her adult son,
  Mark Hicks.Â  Lanelle Hicks looked out a window and saw McMillian, so she went
  to her sonâ€™s room to wake him.Â  At that point, McMillianâ€™s knocking turned into
  beating on the door, and then he crashed the door open, damaging the door.Â  As
  soon as McMillian entered the house, however, Mark Hicks took McMillian back
  outside and held him there with the assistance of a neighbor until the police
  arrived.Â  
McMillian
  subsequently pled guilty to the charge of first-degree burglary.Â  At the plea
  proceeding, McMillian stated that he â€œhad been drinking and druggingâ€ (with
  crack cocaine) the night of the incident and that he thought someone was
  chasing him and trying to kill him.Â  McMillian maintained he knocked on the
  door of the Hicks home in order to get some help, but he admitted that he pushed
  the door open to get inside the home.Â  McMillian stated he believed he â€œwas
  justified in asking for help,â€ but admitted that he â€œknow[s] that [he] did
  wrong.â€Â  
In contrast, the
  solicitor advised the plea judge that according to the victims they never heard
  McMillian ask for help and â€œhe never asked for the police.Â  All he did was kick
  their door in and rip the door jam off.â€Â  Earlier in the plea proceeding, the
  solicitor noted that McMillian has a criminal record dating back to 1977 that
  includes prior convictions for, among other things, housebreaking, malicious
  injury to real property, second-degree burglary, and strong armed robbery.
In a separate
  sentencing proceeding, McMillian again admitted he â€œpushed the door open,â€ but
  maintained he did not â€œgo there with the intent to take anything.â€Â  The plea
  judge sentenced McMillian to nineteen years in prison for first-degree
  burglary.Â  No direct appeal was taken.Â  
McMillian filed a
  PCR application.Â  At the PCR hearing, McMillian asserted, among his claims,
  that his attorney did not explain to him that the State must prove not only
  that he had broken into the victimsâ€™ home, but that he did so with the intent
  to commit a crime.Â  He maintained he would have exercised his right to go to
  trial and would not have pled guilty if his attorney had properly advised him
  that there was no evidence to support an inference of his intent to commit a
  crime.Â Â  
McMillianâ€™s counsel
  testified that she believed there was evidence of intent to commit a crime and
  that she had advised McMillian of all the elements of first-degree burglary.Â 
  Counsel stated, â€œI explained that to Mr. McMillian, that the intent could be
  inferred from the trespassing because it was not his property, and he was
  illegally on someone elseâ€™s property, and he broke the door down of -- pushed
  the door open.Â  I said that it could be inferred from -- trespass could be with
  the intent to commit a crime.Â  Trespass could be inferred from these actions.â€Â  
Counsel stated she
  hired a private investigator to look into McMillianâ€™s story that he had been
  chased by someone and, â€œ[a]fter a period of time . . . he [McMillian] said the
  person kind of existed in his head, I guess.â€Â  She said a neighbor saw
  McMillian â€œlooking in the windows of the home prior to him just bursting in the
  door.â€Â  Thus, she could not substantiate McMillianâ€™s claim that he believed
  someone was chasing him.Â  
McMillianâ€™s PCR
  attorney contended McMillianâ€™s assertion that he was high on drugs and thought
  he was being chased when he went to the home did not support a charge of
  first-degree burglary, as he had no intent to commit a crime, and plea counsel
  erred in advising him that intent to commit a crime could be inferred from an
  act of trespass.Â  
The PCR judge
  denied McMillianâ€™s application and found the allegation that there was no
  factual basis to support a plea to first-degree burglary was without merit.Â 
  The judge noted:Â  â€œCounsel testified that had she gone to trial, intent to
  commit a crime could be inferred from the act of trespassing.Â  Applicant
  testified that he did not own the house and did not have permission to enter
  the house.Â  Further, the evidence suggested that he physically broke the door
  open to enter.Â  Accordingly, this allegation is denied and dismissed.â€Â  
McMillianâ€™s
  attorney submitted a Johnson[2] petition for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR order.Â  This Court directed
  the parties to brief the following issue:Â  Was counsel ineffective in advising
  McMillian that the intent to commit a crime could be inferred from the act of
  trespassing, such that it would provide a factual basis to support a plea to
  first-degree burglary?
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Sixth Amendment
  to the United States Constitution guarantees a defendant the right to effective
  assistance of counsel.Â  U.S. Const. amend. VI; Strickland v. Washington,
  466 U.S. 668 (1984); Lomax v. State, 379 S.C. 93, 665 S.E.2d 164
  (2008).Â  
The United States
  Supreme Court has announced a two-pronged test to establish ineffective
  assistance of counsel by which a PCR applicant must show (1) counselâ€™s performance
  was deficient, and (2) the deficient performance prejudiced the defendant.Â  Strickland,
  466 U.S. at 687; Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989).Â 
  Under the second prong, the PCR applicant â€œmust show that there is a reasonable
  probability that, but for counselâ€™s unprofessional errors, the result of the
  proceeding would have been different.â€Â  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 694.
The two-part test
  adopted in Strickland also â€œapplies to challenges to guilty pleas based
  on ineffective assistance of counsel.â€Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 58 (1985).Â  In the context of a guilty plea, the applicant â€œmust show that there
  is a reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, he would not have
  pleaded guilty and would have insisted on going to trial.â€Â  Id. at 59.Â  â€œThe
  longstanding test for determining the validity of a guilty plea is â€˜whether the
  plea represents a voluntary and intelligent choice among the alternative
  courses of action open to the defendant.â€™â€Â  Id. at 56 (quoting North
    Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25, 31 (1970)).
â€œIn a PCR
  proceeding, the burden is on the applicant to prove the allegations in his
  application.â€Â  Lounds v. State, 380 S.C. 454, 460, 670 S.E.2d 646,
  649 (2008).Â  â€œIn resolving PCR issues relating to guilty pleas, it is
  proper to consider the guilty plea transcript as well as the evidence at the
  PCR hearing.â€Â  Pelzer v. State, 381 S.C. 217, 222, 672 S.E.2d 790,
  792 (Ct. App. 2009).
â€œThis Court will
  uphold the findings of the PCR judge when there is any evidence of probative
  value to support them.â€Â  Suber v. State, 371 S.C. 554, 558, 640 S.E.2d
  884, 886 (2007).Â  â€œThis Court will reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision when
  it is controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Id. at 558-59, 640 S.E.2d at 886.
First-degree
  burglary is a statutory offense in South Carolina that is defined as follows:Â 
  â€œA person is guilty of burglary in the first degree if the person enters a
  dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime in the
  dwelling, andâ€ any one of several enumerated aggravating circumstances
  exists.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311(A) (2003) (emphasis added).Â  In this case,
  the aggravating circumstance is â€œthe
  entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.â€Â  Id. Â§
  16-11-311(A)(3).Â Â Â  
On review,
  McMillian asserts he received ineffective assistance of counsel because
  â€œ[t]here is ambiguous precedent on whether one can infer intent [to commit a
  crime] from trespassing.â€Â  
This Court has
  previously held that for a charge under the old statute of housebreaking, i.e.,
  breaking and entering into a dwelling with the intent to commit a felony or a
  crime of a lesser grade, found in section 1139 of the South Carolina Code of
  1932, the element of intent to commit a crime of a lesser grade could be
  satisfied by a trespass.Â  See State v. Christensen, 194
  S.C. 131, 9 S.E.2d 555 (1940).Â  In Christensen, â€œthe defendant was
  convicted of breaking and entering with the intent to commit a misdemeanor, to
  wit, a trespassâ€ after the defendant, who was an agent of the landlord, went
  into a tenantâ€™s dwelling with the specific intent of taking personal property
  to sell for overdue rent.Â  Id. at 138, 9 S.E.2d at 558.Â  
The Christensen Court cited a prior decision that stated the mere breaking and entering of a
  house is not a crime under the statute prohibiting the breaking and entering
  into a dwelling with the intent to commit a felony or a crime of a lesser
  grade,[3] but found that if Christensen were guilty of a trespass, â€œ[i]t was for the jury
  to say whether such breaking and entry under the circumstances constituted a
  crime under Section 1139 and the finding of the jury on this issue will not be
  disturbed by this Court.â€Â  Id. at 137-39, 9 S.E.2d at 558-59. 
McMillian argues
  counsel was ineffective in advising him that intent to commit a crime could be
  inferred from a trespass.Â  We disagree.Â  In its general sense, to â€œtrespassâ€ is
  â€œto make an unwarranted or uninvited incursionâ€ onto the property of another.Â  Websterâ€™s
    Third New International Dictionary 2439 (2002).[4]Â 
  Â Â 
Certainly, a jury
  would have been free to disbelieve McMillianâ€™s version of events and find that
  he had the intent to commit a crime based on his conduct at the time of this
  offense.Â  In State v. Haney, 257 S.C. 89, 91, 184 S.E.2d 344, 345
  (1971), this Court observed that â€œproof of intent necessarily rests on inference
  from conduct.â€Â  We noted the unexplained breaking and entry of a dwelling in
  the night is itself evidence of intent to commit larceny:

  When the
    building entered is a dwelling house, the weight of authority holds that the unexplained
    breaking and entry in the night is itself evidence of intent to commit larceny
    rather than some other crime.Â  â€˜The fundamental theory, in the absence of other
    intent or explanation for breaking and entering, is that the usual object or
    purpose of burglarizing a dwelling house at night is theft.â€™Â  13 Am.Jur.2d
    Burglary, Sec. 52 (1964).

Id. at 91-92, 184 S.E.2d at 345.Â  A similar view was
  expressed by the Supreme Court of Wyoming, which stated:

  The law
    is well settled and widespread that where one breaks into the property of
    another in the nighttime, an inference may be drawn that he did so with the
    intent to commit larceny.Â  A reasonable mind recognizes that people do not
    usually break into and enter the building of another under the shroud of darkness
    with innocent intent and that the most usual intent is to steal. . . .Â  Direct
    evidence to prove intent is not necessary. . . .Â  Proof of intent is not a
    precise process.

Mirich v. State, 593 P.2d 590, 593 (Wyo. 1979).
Moreover, even if
  we interpret McMillianâ€™s argument as being that counsel was ineffective because
  she referred to unlawful trespass and he did not meet the elements of an
  unlawful trespass because there was no entry after notice, we find there is no
  merit to this allegation.Â  There was notice against entry in this case because,
  as we noted in Christensen, â€œthe presence of closed doors and locked
  windows [i]s notice to the world that entry is forbidden.â€Â  Christensen,
  194 S.C. at 141, 9 S.E.2d at 560. Â 
McMillian was
  facing a possible sentence of life in prison[5] and, based on the colloquy in the transcript, it appears he had hoped for a
  suspended sentence of less than fifteen years.Â  When that did not occur, he
  brought this PCR action.Â  We hold that the fact that counsel advised McMillian that
  a jury could disbelieve his version of events and could find that
  he entered the dwelling without consent and with the intent to commit a crime was
  not erroneous advice and counsel was not deficient in her representation. Accordingly,
  the PCR judge did not err in denying McMillianâ€™s PCR application.
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the order of the PCR judge is
AFFIRMED. 
TOAL, C.J. and
  KITTREDGE, J., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion in which
WALLER, J., concurs.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority that counsel was not
  ineffective in advising petitioner that a jury could find the requisite intent
  to commit a crime for purposes of burglary from his trespass into the Hicksâ€™
  home.Â  I write separately, however, as I do not join the discussion of
  statutory â€œtrespass after noticeâ€ as I believe it is not implicated by these
  facts. See State v. Bradley, 126 S.C. 528, 120 S.E. 240 (1923); State
    v. Cross, 323 S.C. 41, 448 S.E.2d 569 (Ct. App. 1994) (common law trespass
  discussed). 
WALLER, J., concurs.


[1]Â  Ervin McMillian is also referred to as â€œErvin
  Brittonâ€ in various documents in the Appendix.Â  
[2]Â  Johnson v. State, 294 S.C. 310, 364 S.E.2d
  201 (1988).
[3]Â Â  The Christensen Court cited State v.
  Clark, 85 S.C. 273, 67 S.E. 300 (1910), which provides in relevant part as
  follows:Â  

  The
    first count of the indictment is laid under section 145 of the Criminal Code,
    which is as follows:Â  â€œEvery person who shall break and enter, or who shall
    break with intent to enter, in the day time, any dwelling house or other house,
    or who shall break and enter, or shall break with intent to enter, in the night
    time, any house, the breaking and entering of which would not constitute
    burglary, with intent to commit a felony or other crime of a lesser grade,
    shall be held guilty of a felony,â€ etc.Â  Under this statute, the mere breaking of a house is not a crime, nor is the mere breaking and entering of a
    house, or the mere breaking with intent to enter a house any crime.Â  It
    is only when there is a breaking and entering, or a breaking with intent to
    enter, â€œwith intent to commit a felony, or other crime of a lesser gradeâ€
    that the crime denounced by the statute is complete.


  Id. at 277-78, 67 S.E. at 302 (emphasis in original). 
[4]Â  In contrast, an unlawful trespass, or what is
  commonly called trespass after notice, is distinguishable and is prohibited by section
  16-11-620 of the South Carolina Code, which provides as follows:

  Any
    person who, without legal cause or good excuse, enters into the dwelling house,
    place of business, or on the premises of another person after having been
    warned not to do so or any person who, having entered into the dwelling house,
    place of business, or on the premises of another person without having been
    warned fails and refuses, without good cause or good excuse, to leave
    immediately upon being ordered or requested to do so by the person in
    possession or his agent or representative shall, on conviction, be fined not
    more than two hundred dollars or be imprisoned for not more than thirty days.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Dan F.
      Williamson and Dan F. Williamson and Company, Petitioners,
				v.
				Alfred C.
      Middleton, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Greenville County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26689
Heard April 9, 2009 - Filed July 27, 2009Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Desa
  Ballard, of West Columbia, for Petitioners.
				James
  C. Parham, Jr., Wallace K. Lightsey, and Patricia S. Ravenhorst, all of Wyche,
  Burgess, Freeman & Parham, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Following litigation between
  Petitioners Dan F. Williamson and Dan F. Williamson and Company (collectively
  "Williamson") and Respondent Alfred C. Middleton ("Middleton"), a former
  employee, the trial court awarded Middleton $35,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The
  Court of Appeals upheld the award after en banc rehearing. Â Williamson
    v. Middleton, 374 S.C. 419, 649 S.E.2d 57 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  We granted certiorari.Â 
  Williamson argues that the Court of Appeals committed various errors in hearing
  the case en banc, that there is no evidence on which to affirm the
  finding that Middleton would pay his attorneys, and that the attorneyâ€™s fees
  are unreasonable.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Middleton
  worked for a number of years for Williamson as a salesman.Â  Middleton received
  both an annual salary and commissions on sales contracts.Â  During his
  employment, there was a dispute as to the amount of salary and commissions owed
  Middleton and he eventually resigned.
Middleton went to
  work with one of Williamsonâ€™s suppliers.Â  He continued to seek commissions he
  was due but Williamson refused his requests.Â  Middleton then consulted with
  James C. Parham of the Wyche Burgess law firm, who was a personal friend of
  Middleton.Â  On behalf of Middleton, Parham attempted to secure the payment of
  the commissions.Â  Ultimately, Williamson filed suit against Middleton alleging
  breach of fiduciary duty, among other things.Â  Middleton timely filed an Answer
  denying the allegations contained in the Complaint and asserting counterclaims
  based on the alleged non-payment of the commissions and wages owed him.
From
  the beginning, Williamson hindered the progress of the case by making vague and
  incomplete responses to interrogatories, cancelling multiple depositions and
  mediation at the last-minute, and attempting to add new parties and causes of
  action to the lawsuit despite the trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion to amend the
  pleadings.Â  Williamsonâ€™s actions required Middletonâ€™s counsel to devote
  additional time to the case.
At
  trial, only Williamsonâ€™s cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty went to
  the jury, which returned a verdict in favor of Middleton.Â  The jury also
  considered Middletonâ€™s counterclaim for unpaid commissions and awarded him
  $906.62 in actual damages.Â  The trial judge found Middleton was entitled to
  attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  After Middleton presented records showing attorneysâ€™ fees
  totaling approximately $106,000, the trial judge awarded $35,000 in attorneysâ€™
  fees.Â  Williamson appealed to the Court of Appeals which reversed the award.Â  Middleton
  petitioned for rehearing and the Court of Appeals granted rehearing en banc.Â 
  The Court of Appeals en banc voted 5-4 to affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision.
  Â Williamson, supra.
ISSUES

	
		
			I.
			Did the Court of Appeals err in
  granting and conducting rehearing en banc?
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the Court of Appeals err in
  concluding that there was competent evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s
  finding that there was a fee agreement?
		
	

DISCUSSION
I.  Court of Appeals Procedural
  Issues
Williamson
  argues on appeal that the Court of Appeals committed a number of procedural
  errors in granting and conducting rehearing en banc.Â  We find no error.
Following
  the decision by the three-judge panel, Middleton petitioned for rehearing of
  the case and the Court of Appeals granted rehearing en banc.Â  Though the endorsement letter showing that the Court
  of Appeals granted rehearing en banc shows the signatures of only five
  judges, six judges actually voted for rehearing.[1]Â 
  After rehearing, the Court of Appeals en
    banc voted 5-4 to affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision. Â 
Williamson
  first argues that the Court of Appeals erred in granting rehearing en banc on the votes of only five judges because S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-8-90(a)(1)
  requires six votes to hear a case en banc. S.C. Code Ann. 14-8-90(a)(1)
  (2008).Â  As referenced above, a letter from the Clerk of the Court of Appeals
  explained that the signature of Judge Williams was mistakenly omitted from the
  endorsement letter.Â  In fact, the Clerk explained that six judges voted to hear
  the case en banc.Â  Consequently, Williamsonâ€™s argument is without
  merit.Â  Next, Williamson contends that even if six judges voted to hear the
  case en banc, sufficient grounds did not exist to support rehearing
  under Rule 219 of the South Carolina Appellate Court Rules (SCACR).Â  We note
  that while Rule 219 lists certain grounds on which rehearing en banc may
  be granted, it provides only that rehearing en banc "ordinarily will not be ordered" except upon the listed grounds. Â Rule 219, SCACR (2007)
  (emphasis added).Â  The Court of Appeals has discretion as to whether or not to
  accept rehearing and we find no error in the exercise of such discretion here. 
Williamson
  next argues that six votes of the Court of Appeals en banc were required
  to uphold the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Williamson notes that S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  14-8-90(b) requires six votes of the en banc panel to reverse "the
  judgment below."Â  In Williamsonâ€™s view, "the judgment below" is the opinion of
  the three-judge panel rather than the decision of the trial court.Â  We disagree
  and find no error. Â See Rule 202(b)(1), SCACR (2007) (defining term
  "lower court" as "the circuit court . . . from which the appeal is taken"); State
    v. McAteer, 333 S.C. 615, 616, 511 S.E.2d 79, 80 (Ct. App. 1998), overruled
      on other grounds, 340 S.C. 644, 532 S.E.2d 865 (2000) (granting of
  rehearing en banc by the Court of Appeals effectively vacates the
  original panel opinion).
Williamsonâ€™s
  final procedural argument is that the Court of Appeals erred in failing to
  limit its review to the existence or non-existence of a fee agreement, since in
  Williamsonâ€™s view, the Court of Appeals granted rehearing only as to this
  issue.Â  We disagree.

II.  Did the Court of Appeals
  err in concluding there was competent evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s
  finding of a fee agreement?
The
  jury awarded Middleton $906.62 for unpaid commissions pursuant to S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 39-65-20 (2008), which requires that when a contract between a sales
  representative and principal is terminated, the principal must pay all
  commissions due.Â  When an employer violates Â§ 39-65-20, Â§ 39-65-30 provides
  that the employer is liable for "attorneyâ€™s fees actually and reasonably
  incurred by the sales representative in the action and court costs." Â S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 39-65-30 (2008).
Williamson
  argues that the Court of Appeals en banc erred in finding that competent
  evidence supports the finding that fees were incurred.Â  We agree.
Middletonâ€™s
  counsel was deposed on the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  He acknowledged that he
  and Middleton were personal friends, that he had handled other legal matters
  for Middleton in the past without taking a fee, and that Middleton was never
  sent any statements of attorneyâ€™s fees incurred.Â  Furthermore, Middletonâ€™s
  counsel answered in the negative when specifically asked if Middleton incurred
  any attorneyâ€™s fees:

	
		
			Q.
			Has Mr. Middleton incurred any attorneyâ€™s fees from 
			this representation?
 
		
		
			A.
			No, technically, he hasnâ€™t because we donâ€™t have a 
			fee agreement with Mr. Middleton.  We talked about this with 
			Mr. Middleton to begin with and we decided that we would try to help 
			him collect the monies due him and at the end of the case, we would 
			talk about a fee.  So we donâ€™t have a fee agreement with him.  
			But some day, he might pay us a fee.  Right now, he has no 
			obligation at this point if there is no agreement.  He might 
			feel a moral obligation.  And when we talk at the end of the 
			case, he will have the final say.
		
	

The Court
  of Appeals en banc found competent evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s
  conclusion that attorneyâ€™s fees were incurred.Â  The majority noted that the
  statement cited by Williamson could be interpreted in different ways:

	While Parhamâ€™s testimony . . . could be interpreted to
  mean Middleton would never be required to pay a fee, it also indicates that "at
  the end of the case, [Middleton and his attorneys] would talk about a fee."Â  [The
  trial court] adopted this latter interpretation . . . .

Williamson, 374 S.C. at 429, 649 S.E.2d at 63.
We
  find no competent evidence to support the finding that Middleton incurred
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Though Middletonâ€™s counsel did indeed indicate that he and
  Middleton would "talk about a fee" at the conclusion of the case, he also
  explained that Middleton had no obligation other than a moral obligation to pay
  a fee and that Middleton would have the final say.Â  In our view, the only
  logical interpretation of the statement by Middletonâ€™s counsel is that
  Middleton could choose not to pay a fee to his counsel.Â  It therefore follows
  that no attorneyâ€™s fees were incurred.[2]
As
  evidence that attorneyâ€™s fees were actually incurred, the Court of Appeals en
    banc noted that Parham testified that he was "hired" by Middleton in the
  Spring of 2001 and had kept extensive and diligent records detailing the amount
  of time spent on the case and by whom the work was done.Â  The Court of Appeals en
    banc also found that it was unlikely that Middletonâ€™s second-chair
  attorney, Wyche associate Patricia Ravenhorst, who had no prior relationship
  with Middleton, would have volunteered her time with no expectation of being
  paid.Â  We find that these facts simply cannot overcome the candid admission by
  Middletonâ€™s counsel that no fees were incurred.[3]
CONCLUSION
The
  Court of Appeals did not err in granting and conducting rehearing en banc.Â 
  On the merits, we find no evidence to support the finding of the Court of
  Appeals that Middleton incurred attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm the remaining
  issues under Rule 220(b), SCACR.Â  Therefore, the decision of the Court of
  Appeals is
REVERSED. 
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justices Ellis B. Drew and S. Jackson
  Kimball, concur.


[1] The signature of Judge Bruce Williams was mistakenly omitted from the
  endorsement letter.
[2] At oral argument, Middletonâ€™s counsel argued that the recent opinion in Kiriakides
  v. School Dist. of Greenville County, 382 S.C. 8, 675 S.E.2d 439 (2009),
  governs this case.Â  We disagree.Â  In Kiriakides, we found "no reason to
  differentiate situations where a party terminates the attorney and those where
  the condemnor terminates the proceeding."Â  Id. at 24, 675 S.E.2d at 448.Â 
  We therefore upheld the award of attorneysâ€™ fees where the client had a
  contingency fee agreement with his attorneys and the opposing party abandoned
  the condemnation action that was the subject of the litigation.Â  Id. at 25, 675 S.E.2d at 448.Â  The instant case does not concern a terminated
  proceeding in which the court must consider implied fees, but rather a
  completed proceeding in which the attorney testified that no fees were owed.Â Â  
[3] Because we find that no evidence supports the Court of Appeals finding that
  attorneyâ€™s fees were incurred, we do not reach Williamsonâ€™s argument that the
  fees awarded were unreasonable.
